facts.text: Tardigrades, microscopic eight-legged animals, can survive being frozen to near absolute zero (-272°C), boiled at 150°C, exposed to the vacuum of space, and blasted with radiation 1,000 times stronger than what would kill a human. When conditions become too harsh, they expel nearly all water from their bodies, retract their legs, and enter a death-like state called cryptobiosis where they can survive for decades until rehydrated.
facts.verification_note: All stated claims about tardigrade survival capabilities and cryptobiosis are well-documented in peer-reviewed scientific literature, including their tolerance to extreme temperatures, radiation (up to ~5,000-6,200 Gy vs. ~5-10 Gy lethal to humans), vacuum exposure, and decades-long survival in desiccated states.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a split-scene composition showing a magnified tardigrade as the central figure—a translucent, bear-like creature with eight stubby legs tipped with claws, rendered in luminous pale blue and amber tones against a dark cosmic background. The left side shows the tardigrade in its active state, plump and glowing with internal fluids, while the right side displays its cryptobiotic form: a shriveled, barrel-shaped tun with retracted legs, appearing almost crystalline and dehydrated. Surrounding the tardigrade are visual representations of extreme conditions—ice crystals, flame wisps, radiation symbols rendered as ethereal green waves, and distant stars in the vacuum of space—all in a semi-photorealistic scientific illustration style with dramatic lighting that makes the creature appear both alien and resilient. Small water droplets should be shown being expelled from the creature's body during transformation, catching light like tiny prisms, while a subtle timeline indicator suggests the decades-long suspended animation.

<svg width="800" height="600" viewBox="0 0 800 600" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">

    </radialGradient>
    
    <radialGradient id="tardigradeActive" cx="40%" cy="30%" r="60%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#e8f4ff;stop-opacity:0.9" />
      <stop offset="40%" style="stop-color:#4da6ff;stop-opacity:0.8" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#2d5a7f;stop-opacity:0.7" />
    </radialGradient>
    
    <radialGradient id="tardigradeTun" cx="40%" cy="30%" r="60%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#ffecd6;stop-opacity:0.9" />
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#d4a574;stop-opacity:0.8" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#8b6f47;stop-opacity:0.7" />
    </radialGradient>
    
    <radialGradient id="glow" cx="50%" cy="50%" r="50%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#ffffff;stop-opacity:0.6" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#4da6ff;stop-opacity:0" />
    </radialGradient>
    
    <radialGradient id="radiation" cx="50%" cy="50%" r="50%">

      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#00ff88;stop-opacity:0" />
    </radialGradient>
    
    <linearGradient id="flame" x1="0%" y1="100%" x2="0%" y2="0%">

    <filter id="glow-filter">

  </defs>
  
  <!-- Cosmic Background -->

  <!-- Stars -->

  <circle cx="680" cy="90" r="1.5" fill="#ffffff" opacity="0.9"/>
  <circle cx="720" cy="150" r="1" fill="#ffffff" opacity="0.7"/>
  <circle cx="650" cy="200" r="1.2" fill="#ffffff" opacity="0.8"/>
  <circle cx="120" cy="450" r="1" fill="#ffffff" opacity="0.6"/>
  <circle cx="700" cy="480" r="1.3" fill="#ffffff" opacity="0.7"/>
  <circle cx="50" cy="250" r="1.1" fill="#ffffff" opacity="0.8"/>
  
  <!-- Left Side - Ice Crystals -->

    <ellipse cx="730" cy="380" rx="18" ry="45" fill="url(#flame)" filter="url(#blur)"/>

    <circle cx="-25" cy="55" r="2" fill="#2d5a7f"/>
    
    <path d="M 10 25 Q 5 45 10 55" fill="none" stroke="#4da6ff" stroke-width="4" stroke-linecap="round" opacity="0.8"/>

    <circle cx="45" cy="40" r="2" fill="#2d5a7f"/>

  <g opacity="0.7">

    <path d="M -20 20 Q -10 30 -20 40" fill="none" stroke="#8b6f47" stroke-width="1" opacity="0.5"/>
    <path d="M 0 25 Q 10 35 0 45" fill="none" stroke="#8b6f47" stroke-width="1" opacity="0.5"/>
    <path d="M 20 20 Q 10 30 20 40" fill="none" stroke="#8b6f47" stroke-width="1" opacity="0.5"/>
    
    <!-- Retracted leg indicators (subtle bumps) -->
    <ellipse cx="-30" cy="-20" rx="8" ry="10" fill="#d4a574" opacity="0.6"/>
    <ellipse cx="-30" cy="20" rx="8" ry="10" fill="#d4a574" opacity="0.6"/>
    <ellipse cx="30" cy="-20" rx="8" ry="10" fill="#d4a574" opacity="0.6"/>
    <ellipse cx="30" cy="20" rx="8" ry="10" fill="#d4a574" opacity="0.6"/>
    
    <!-- Crystalline highlights -->
    <path d="M -15 -35 L -10 -30 L -15 -25" fill="none" stroke="#ffffff" stroke-width="1.5" opacity="0.6"/>
    <path d="M 10 -30 L 15 -25 L 10 -20" fill="none" stroke="#ffffff" stroke-width="1.5" opacity="0.6"/>
    <circle cx="-5" cy="0" r="3" fill="#ffffff" opacity="0.4"/>
    <circle cx="12" cy="15" r="2" fill="#ffffff" opacity="0.5"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Vacuum of Space Representation -->
  <g opacity="0.3">

  <!-- Additional environmental indicators -->

  <text x="650" y="520" font-family="monospace" font-size="12" fill="#ff8844" opacity="0.5">+150°C</text>
</svg>

facts.text: When you get goosebumps, you're experiencing a vestigial reflex from our furry ancestors—the tiny muscles at the base of each hair contract to make fur stand up, which would have made them look bigger to predators or trap warm air. Humans lost most of our body hair millions of years ago, but our bodies still perform this now-useless display, creating the bumpy skin texture instead of an impressive fur puff.
facts.verification_note: The claim accurately describes the piloerection reflex (goosebumps) as a vestigial response controlled by arrector pili muscles that once served thermoregulatory and defensive functions in our hairier ancestors but now produces minimal functional benefit in humans.
facts.image_description: The illustration should be split diagonally, showing a photorealistic close-up of human skin with goosebumps on the upper left, with each hair follicle raised and tiny bumps visible in cool blue-tinted lighting, while the lower right transitions into the same anatomical area covered in thick, bristling fur standing on end, rendered in warm amber tones. Beneath the surface on both sides, translucent cross-section layers reveal the arrector pili muscles in red, contracted and pulling at the hair follicles like tiny biological pulleys. The style should blend medical illustration precision with dramatic lighting—perhaps a rim light highlighting each raised hair—while a faded silhouette of both a human figure and a prehistoric furry hominid appears in the background, creating a visual timeline of evolution that emphasizes the vestigial nature of this reflex.

facts.text: When you get a sunburn, the damage isn't actually caused by the sun's UV rays directly—it's your own body's cells committing suicide. Your skin cells detect DNA damage from UV radiation and self-destruct through programmed cell death (apoptosis) to prevent potential cancer, which is what causes the redness, peeling, and pain of a sunburn.
facts.verification_note: UV radiation does cause direct DNA damage, but the characteristic sunburn symptoms (redness, peeling, pain) occur hours later and are primarily caused by programmed cell death (apoptosis) of damaged keratinocytes and the resulting inflammatory response, which is indeed the body's protective mechanism to eliminate cells with potentially cancerous mutations.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a cross-section of human skin in a semi-scientific, stylized manner with dramatic lighting—golden-orange UV rays penetrating from above through translucent upper skin layers. In the deeper layers, individual skin cells are shown as glowing, translucent spheres with visible DNA helixes inside; some cells display fractured, red-glowing DNA strands and are actively fragmenting into smaller pieces with soft particle effects, while releasing warm red and pink halos that spread outward to represent inflammation. The composition should contrast the cool blue-purple tones of healthy cells on the edges with increasingly warm reds, oranges, and yellows toward the center of UV exposure, creating a visual gradient of cellular self-destruction. Small, ghost-like wisps should rise from the self-destructing cells toward the surface, representing the peeling dead skin, while maintaining a balance between scientific accuracy and artistic drama through soft bioluminescent glows and precise cellular detail.

facts.text: Wombats are the only animals that produce cube-shaped feces, which they stack to mark territory and prevent them from rolling away. Scientists discovered this happens because wombat intestines have varying elasticity in different sections, literally molding the poop into cubes during the final 8% of the digestive process.
facts.verification_note: Research published in 2021 confirmed that wombats produce cube-shaped feces due to varying elasticity in their intestinal walls during the final 8% of digestion, and they do use these cubes to mark territory as they don't roll away.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a cross-sectional, semi-transparent anatomical view of a wombat in profile, rendered in a detailed scientific illustration style with warm earth tones and soft natural lighting. The intestinal tract should be prominently visible through the translucent body, with color-coded sections showing varying elasticity—deep burgundy for rigid sections and soft pink for elastic areas—with small arrows or labels indicating the pressure points that form the cubic shape. In the foreground, a realistic wombat should be shown stacking several dark brown, perfectly geometric cube-shaped droppings on a rock or log, while an inset diagram in the corner displays a magnified view of the final 8% of the intestine with the feces transforming from round to cubic. The background should feature muted Australian bushland in soft focus, with golden-hour lighting that creates subtle shadows emphasizing the geometric edges of the cube-shaped droppings.

    <linearGradient id="logGradient" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="0%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#6b4423;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#8b5a3c;stop-opacity:1" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <filter id="glow">
      <feGaussianBlur stdDeviation="2" result="coloredBlur"/>
      <feMerge>
        <feMergeNode in="coloredBlur"/>
        <feMergeNode in="SourceGraphic"/>
      </feMerge>
    </filter>
  </defs>
  
  <!-- Sky -->
  <rect width="800" height="400" fill="url(#skyGradient)"/>
  
  <!-- Ground -->
  <rect y="400" width="800" height="200" fill="url(#groundGradient)"/>
  
  <!-- Bushland silhouettes (soft focus) -->
  <ellipse cx="100" cy="380" rx="80" ry="60" fill="#8a7355" opacity="0.4"/>
  <ellipse cx="250" cy="390" rx="100" ry="70" fill="#9b8470" opacity="0.3"/>
  <ellipse cx="700" cy="385" rx="90" ry="65" fill="#8a7355" opacity="0.35"/>
  
  <!-- Log/Rock for stacking -->
  <ellipse cx="180" cy="500" rx="100" ry="30" fill="#5a3a2a" opacity="0.3"/>
  <rect x="80" y="480" width="200" height="40" rx="10" fill="url(#logGradient)"/>
  <ellipse cx="180" cy="480" rx="100" ry="15" fill="#8b5a3c" opacity="0.6"/>
  
  <!-- Wombat body (semi-transparent, profile view) -->
  <g id="wombat">
    <!-- Main body outline -->
    <ellipse cx="450" cy="380" rx="140" ry="100" fill="url(#wombatBody)" stroke="#5a4538" stroke-width="2"/>
    
    <!-- Head -->
    <ellipse cx="330" cy="340" rx="60" ry="55" fill="url(#wombatBody)" stroke="#5a4538" stroke-width="2"/>
    
    <!-- Ear -->
    <ellipse cx="320" cy="310" rx="18" ry="25" fill="#9b8470" stroke="#5a4538" stroke-width="1"/>
    
    <!-- Eye -->
    <circle cx="310" cy="335" r="5" fill="#2d1810"/>
    
    <!-- Nose -->
    <ellipse cx="295" cy="355" rx="8" ry="6" fill="#3d2618"/>
    
    <!-- Legs (simplified) -->
    <rect x="380" y="450" width="35" height="60" rx="10" fill="#7a6454" opacity="0.8"/>
    <rect x="480" y="450" width="35" height="60" rx="10" fill="#7a6454" opacity="0.8"/>
    
    <!-- Intestinal tract - complex curved path -->
    <g id="intestines" opacity="0.9">
      <!-- Upper intestine (elastic - pink) -->
      <path d="M 420 340 Q 460 320 500 340 Q 520 360 510 390" 
            stroke="url(#intestineElastic)" stroke-width="12" fill="none" stroke-linecap="round"/>
      
      <!-- Mid intestine (mixed) -->
      <path d="M 510 390 Q 500 410 480 420 Q 450 430 430 420" 
            stroke="#d48fa0" stroke-width="12" fill="none" stroke-linecap="round"/>
      
      <!-- Lower intestine sections with varying elasticity -->
      <path d="M 430 420 Q 410 415 400 400" 
            stroke="url(#intestineRigid)" stroke-width="10" fill="none" stroke-linecap="round"/>
      
      <path d="M 400 400 Q 395 385 405 370" 
            stroke="url(#intestineElastic)" stroke-width="10" fill="none" stroke-linecap="round"/>
      
      <path d="M 405 370 Q 415 360 425 365" 
            stroke="url(#intestineRigid)" stroke-width="10" fill="none" stroke-linecap="round"/>
      
      <!-- Final 8% - cube forming section (darker burgundy) -->
      <path d="M 425 365 Q 435 368 440 375 Q 442 385 435 390" 
            stroke="#6b1f35" stroke-width="11" fill="none" stroke-linecap="round" filter="url(#glow)"/>
      
      <!-- Pressure point indicators (small arrows) -->
      <polygon points="398,395 403,398 398,401" fill="#ff6b8a" opacity="0.8"/>
      <polygon points="408,365 413,368 408,371" fill="#ff6b8a" opacity="0.8"/>
      <polygon points="428,368 433,371 428,374" fill="#ff6b8a" opacity="0.8"/>
      <polygon points="440,380 445,383 440,386" fill="#ff6b8a" opacity="0.8"/>
    </g>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Cube-shaped droppings on log -->
  <g id="cubes">
    <!-- Cube 1 (back) -->
    <g transform="translate(140, 460)">
      <polygon points="0,15 12,8 24,15 12,22" fill="url(#cubeShading)"/>
      <polygon points="0,15 0,30 12,37 12,22" fill="#3d2618"/>
      <polygon points="24,15 24,30 12,37 12,22" fill="#2d1810"/>
    </g>
    
    <!-- Cube 2 (middle) -->
    <g transform="translate(170, 455)">
      <polygon points="0,15 14,7 28,15 14,23" fill="url(#cubeShading)"/>
      <polygon points="0,15 0,32 14,40 14,23" fill="#3d2618"/>
      <polygon points="28,15 28,32 14,40 14,23" fill="#2d1810"/>
    </g>
    
    <!-- Cube 3 (front, being placed) -->
    <g transform="translate(205, 450)">
      <polygon points="0,16 15,8 30,16 15,24" fill="url(#cubeShading)"/>
      <polygon points="0,16 0,34 15,42 15,24" fill="#3d2618"/>
      <polygon points="30,16 30,34 15,42 15,24" fill="#2d1810"/>
      <!-- Shadow under cube -->
      <ellipse cx="15" cy="45" rx="18" ry="4" fill="#000" opacity="0.3"/>
    </g>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Inset diagram - magnified intestine section -->
  <g id="insetDiagram">
    <!-- Background box -->
    <rect x="600" y="30" width="180" height="140" rx="8" fill="#f5e6d3" stroke="#8b7355" stroke-width="2"/>
    
    <!-- Title area -->
    <rect x="600" y="30" width="180" height="25" rx="8" fill="#c9a876" opacity="0.5"/>
    
    <!-- Intestine cross-section showing transformation -->
    <g transform="translate(620, 70)">
      <!-- Round feces at start -->
      <circle cx="15" cy="30" r="12" fill="#6b4423" opacity="0.7"/>
      <circle cx="15" cy="30" r="10" fill="#5a3a2a"/>
      
      <!-- Arrow indicating transformation -->
      <path d="M 35 30 L 60 30" stroke="#8b2942" stroke-width="2" marker-end="url(#arrowhead)"/>
      <defs>
        <marker id="arrowhead" markerWidth="10" markerHeight="10" refX="9" refY="3" orient="auto">
          <polygon points="0 0, 10 3, 0 6" fill="#8b2942"/>
        </marker>
      </defs>
      
      <!-- Intermediate shape -->
      <rect x="65" y="20" width="18" height="18" rx="4" fill="#6b4423" opacity="0.8"/>
      
      <!-- Arrow -->
      <path d="M 90 30 L 110 30" stroke="#8b2942" stroke-width="2" marker-end="url(#arrowhead)"/>
      
      <!-- Final cube shape -->
      <g transform="translate(115, 18)">
        <polygon points="0,8 6,4 12,8 6,12" fill="#5a3a2a"/>
        <polygon points="0,8 0,16 6,20 6,12" fill="#3d2618"/>
        <polygon points="12,8 12,16 6,20 6,12" fill="#2d1810"/>
      </g>
    </g>
    
    <!-- Intestine wall representation -->
    <rect x="615" y="120" width="70" height="35" rx="3" fill="url(#intestineRigid)" opacity="0.6"/>
    <rect x="690" y="120" width="80" height="35" rx="3" fill="url(#intestineElastic)" opacity="0.6"/>
    
    <!-- Pressure indicators -->
    <circle cx="625" cy="137" r="3" fill="#ff6b8a"/>
    <circle cx="645" cy="137" r="3" fill="#ff6b8a"/>
    <circle cx="665" cy="137" r="3" fill="#ff6b8a"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Golden hour light rays (subtle) -->
  <g opacity="0.15">
    <path d="M 0 100 L 200 400 L 0 400 Z" fill="#ffd700"/>
    <path d="M 800 150 L 600 400 L 800 400 Z" fill="#ffd700"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Foreground grass elements -->
  <g opacity="0.6">
    <path d="M 50 500 Q 55 480 60 500" stroke="#7a6454" stroke-width="2" fill="none"/>
    <path d="M 120 510 Q 125 490 130 510" stroke="#7a6454" stroke-width="2" fill="none"/>
    <path d="M 750 505 Q 755 485 760 505" stroke="#7a6454" stroke-width="2" fill="none"/>
  </g>
</svg>

facts.text: Neutron stars are so dense that a teaspoon of their material would weigh about 6 billion tons on Earth—roughly the same as if Mount Everest were compressed into a sugar cube. The gravity is so intense that if you dropped an object from one meter above the surface, it would hit the ground at around 7 million kilometers per hour.
facts.verification_note: The density claim is accurate (neutron star matter is ~4×10^17 kg/m³, making a teaspoon weigh ~5-6 billion tons), and the calculated impact velocity from 1 meter drop on a typical neutron star surface (with gravity ~2×10^12 m/s²) yields approximately 7 million km/h.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a split-scene composition in a dramatic photorealistic style with scientific diagram elements: on the left, a glowing teaspoon hovers above a neutron star's surface (rendered with a deep purple-blue crystalline lattice pattern that pulses with intense gravitational distortion), while ghostly comparison images of Mount Everest and a sugar cube float translucently nearby with "=" symbols between them. On the right side, a metallic sphere is captured mid-fall in a motion-blur streak, with speed lines and a digital speedometer displaying "7,000,000 km/h" in bright cyan numbers, while the 1-meter distance is marked with a glowing ruler overlay. The entire scene should be bathed in the eerie blue-white light of the neutron star's magnetic field, with warped space-time grid lines bending dramatically around the star's surface, and corona-like energy emissions creating a halo effect that emphasizes the extreme physics at play.

<svg width="800" height="600" viewBox="0 0 800 600" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">

    </radialGradient>
    
    <radialGradient id="coronaGlow" cx="50%" cy="50%" r="50%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#ffffff;stop-opacity:0.8"/>
      <stop offset="30%" style="stop-color:#00d4ff;stop-opacity:0.5"/>
      <stop offset="60%" style="stop-color:#4a5fc1;stop-opacity:0.3"/>
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#2d1b69;stop-opacity:0"/>
    </radialGradient>
    
    <linearGradient id="teaspoonGradient" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#ffd700;stop-opacity:1"/>
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#ffea00;stop-opacity:0.9"/>

    <filter id="glow">

  <!-- Neutron star surface -->

  <!-- Pulsing energy rings -->

  <!-- Teaspoon glow aura -->

  <!-- Vertical divider line -->

  <!-- RIGHT SIDE: Falling sphere scene -->

  <!-- Falling metallic sphere -->

  <!-- Digital speedometer display -->

    <rect x="525" y="325" width="190" height="50" rx="3" fill="url(#speedometerGlow)" opacity="0.2"/>

  <!-- Additional motion streaks -->

facts.text: The mantis shrimp can throw punches so fast that they create cavitation bubbles in the water, which collapse with a flash of light and temperatures reaching nearly 8,000°F—almost as hot as the surface of the sun. This shockwave alone can kill prey even if the punch misses.
facts.verification_note: Mantis shrimp strikes do create cavitation bubbles that collapse at approximately 4,700-8,000°F (similar to the sun's surface temperature of ~10,000°F) with sonoluminescence (light emission), and the secondary shockwave can indeed stun or kill prey independently of direct contact.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a vibrant peacock mantis shrimp in mid-strike, its club-like appendage extended forward in crystal-clear water, captured in a photorealistic style with scientific diagram elements. The focal point is the explosive cavitation bubble forming at the strike point—rendered as a translucent sphere filled with swirling plasma-like energy in brilliant whites, yellows, and oranges that graduate to intense blue-white at the core, mimicking the 8,000°F heat. Small bioluminescent flashes should radiate outward as concentric shockwave rings, illustrated with subtle motion blur and refraction effects that distort the background water. A small fish or crab should be visible nearby, stunned or tumbling from the shockwave's force despite being just outside the punch's direct path, while an inset diagram in the corner shows the temperature comparison between the bubble and the sun's surface using a color-coded thermometer scale.
facts.image_svg:
<svg width="800" height="600" viewBox="0 0 800 600" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <defs>
    <radialGradient id="waterGradient" cx="50%" cy="50%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#1a5f7a;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#0d2f3f;stop-opacity:1" />
    </radialGradient>

    </radialGradient>

      <stop offset="60%" style="stop-color:#ffffcc;stop-opacity:0.9" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#ffcc00;stop-opacity:0.7" />

    <linearGradient id="shrimpBody" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#00ff88;stop-opacity:1" />

      <stop offset="60%" style="stop-color:#0099cc;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#0066ff;stop-opacity:1" />
    </linearGradient>

      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#ff00ff;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#ff0099;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#cc0066;stop-opacity:1" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <radialGradient id="shockwave" cx="50%" cy="50%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#ffffff;stop-opacity:0" />

      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#ffffff;stop-opacity:0" />
    </radialGradient>
    
    <linearGradient id="thermometer" x1="0%" y1="100%" x2="0%" y2="0%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#0066cc;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="25%" style="stop-color:#00cc99;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#ffff00;stop-opacity:1" />

      <!-- The club (enlarged and powerful) -->
      <ellipse cx="125" cy="26" rx="18" ry="12" fill="#ff0066"/>
      <ellipse cx="125" cy="26" rx="14" ry="9" fill="#ff3388"/>

    </g>
    
    <!-- Additional body detail -->
    <path d="M 35 15 Q 40 20 35 25" stroke="#00ffcc" stroke-width="1" fill="none" opacity="0.5"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Refraction/distortion effects in water around bubble -->
  <ellipse cx="380" cy="270" rx="30" ry="40" fill="none" stroke="#99ccdd" stroke-width="1" opacity="0.3"/>
  <ellipse cx="460" cy="290" rx="35" ry="45" fill="none" stroke="#99ccdd" stroke-width="1" opacity="0.3"/>
  
  <!-- Small particles/debris disturbed by shockwave -->
  <circle cx="500" cy="250" r="2" fill="#cccccc" opacity="0.6"/>
  <circle cx="520" cy="280" r="1.5" fill="#cccccc" opacity="0.5"/>
  <circle cx="340" cy="260" r="2" fill="#cccccc" opacity="0.6"/>
  <circle cx="360" cy="300" r="1.5" fill="#cccccc" opacity="0.5"/>
  <circle cx="480" cy="320" r="1" fill="#cccccc" opacity="0.4"/>
  
  <!-- Temperature comparison diagram (inset) -->
  <g transform="translate(650, 50)">

    <rect x="0" y="0" width="130" height="180" fill="#0d2f3f" opacity="0.85" rx="5"/>

    <line x1="45" y1="110" x2="55" y2="110" stroke="#ffffff" stroke-width="2"/>
    
    <!-- Sun icon -->
    <circle cx="90" cy="40" r="12" fill="#ffff00" filter="url(#glow)"/>
    <line x1="90" y1="25" x2="90" y2="20" stroke="#ffff00" stroke-width="2"/>
    <line x1="90" y1="55" x2="90" y2="60" stroke="#ffff00" stroke-width="2"/>
    <line x1="75" y1="40" x2="70" y2="40" stroke="#ffff00" stroke-width="2"/>
    <line x1="105" y1="40" x2="110" y2="40" stroke="#ffff00" stroke-width="2"/>
    <line x1="80" y1="30" x2="76" y2="26" stroke="#ffff00" stroke-width="2"/>
    <line x1="100" y1="50" x2="104" y2="54" stroke="#ffff00" stroke-width="2"/>
    <line x1="80" y1="50" x2="76" y2="54" stroke="#ffff00" stroke-width="2"/>
    <line x1="100" y1="30" x2="104" y2="26" stroke="#ffff00" stroke-width="2"/>

facts.text: The fungus *Ophiocordyceps unilateralis* infects carpenter ants, hijacks their nervous system, and compels them to climb to a precise height and location with optimal temperature and humidity before clamping their jaws onto a leaf in a "death grip"—all so the fungus can fruit from the ant's head and spread its spores to infect more ants below.
facts.verification_note: Scientific research confirms that Ophiocordyceps unilateralis does infect carpenter ants, manipulates their behavior to climb to elevated locations with specific microclimatic conditions optimal for fungal growth, induces the characteristic death grip on vegetation, and produces fruiting bodies from the ant's body to disperse spores.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a carpenter ant in profile, clamped jaw-first onto the underside of a broad tropical leaf in a misty rainforest understory, with dramatic backlighting filtering through the canopy creating an eerie, luminous green glow. From the ant's head and neck joints, elongated, dark reddish-brown fungal stalks (stromata) emerge and curve upward like alien tendrils, their tips bulbous and textured with spore-releasing structures. The style should blend scientific accuracy with haunting beauty—photorealistic enough to show the ant's segmented body, mandibles locked in rigor mortis, and the fuzzy mycelium creeping across its exoskeleton, while maintaining an almost ethereal quality through soft-focus spores visibly drifting downward in the humid air toward shadowy ant silhouettes on the forest floor below. The color palette should emphasize deep forest greens, amber sunlight rays, the rusty orange-brown of the ant's body contrasting with the wine-dark purple and black of the mature fungal fruiting bodies.

  <circle cx="600" cy="400" r="3" fill="#9ACD32" opacity="0.2" filter="url(#glow)"/>
</svg>

facts.text: When you get a kidney transplant, doctors usually leave your original kidneys inside your body and place the new kidney in a completely different location—typically in your lower abdomen near your pelvis. Most transplant recipients end up with three kidneys total.
facts.verification_note: In standard kidney transplant procedures, the native kidneys are left in place unless there is a specific medical reason for removal (such as infection or cancer), and the donor kidney is surgically placed in the lower abdomen/pelvis, resulting in three total kidneys.
facts.image_description: A cutaway medical illustration in the style of detailed anatomical textbooks shows a translucent human torso against a soft blue-gray gradient background, with the spine and ribcage faintly visible in pale ivory. The two original kidneys are rendered in deep reddish-brown, positioned high in their natural location on either side of the spine, while a third, slightly pinker kidney sits prominently in the lower right abdomen near the pelvis, connected by bright red arterial vessels and blue venous lines that stand out against the muted internal anatomy. Soft directional lighting from the upper left creates subtle shadows that give depth to the organs, while thin white dotted lines and small labels point to each kidney with numbers (1, 2, 3) to emphasize the surprising trio. The illustration balances scientific accuracy with visual clarity, using a clean, modern style that makes the unexpected placement of the transplanted kidney immediately striking and memorable.

facts.text: The Eiffel Tower can grow more than 6 inches taller during summer due to thermal expansion of its iron structure, and it also leans away from the sun by up to 7 inches because the side facing the sun heats up and expands more than the shaded side.
facts.verification_note: The Eiffel Tower's iron structure does expand approximately 6 inches (15 cm) in height during summer heat due to thermal expansion, and differential heating causes the sun-facing side to expand more than the shaded side, creating a measurable lean of up to 7 inches (18 cm) away from the sun.
facts.image_description: A split-panel scientific illustration showing the Eiffel Tower in winter and summer side-by-side against a crisp Parisian skyline. The winter panel features a cooler blue-tinted tower standing perfectly vertical with measurement lines indicating its base height, while the summer panel shows a warm golden-orange tower bathed in bright sunlight, with visible measurement arrows demonstrating both the 6-inch upward growth and the 7-inch lean away from an illustrated blazing sun. The iron lattice structure should be rendered in detailed cross-section on one side, with color gradients from deep orange (sun-facing) to cooler gray (shaded side) to visualize the differential heating, and semi-transparent overlay arrows and dimensional callouts in white and yellow highlighting the expansion vectors in a technical blueprint style.

facts.text: When a pregnant mouse smells the scent of an unfamiliar male mouse, she will spontaneously abort her embryos and become receptive to mating with the new male—a phenomenon called the Bruce effect. This happens because the new male's pheromones trigger a hormonal cascade that prevents the embryos from implanting or causes existing pregnancies to terminate.
facts.verification_note: The Bruce effect is a well-documented phenomenon in mice where exposure to unfamiliar male pheromones causes pregnancy failure in recently-mated females by disrupting prolactin secretion, preventing implantation or terminating early pregnancy.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a split-scene composition in a semi-scientific, slightly stylized manner with muted natural tones. On the left, a white female mouse with subtle pink ears stands in soft, cool blue-gray lighting, her nose lifted toward wisps of golden-yellow pheromone particles drifting through the air like luminescent smoke trails. On the right side, partially obscured in shadow, a darker male mouse is the source of these glowing scent molecules. Within the female mouse's translucent lower abdomen, rendered in delicate cross-section, tiny embryos fade from solid pink to ghostly transparent outlines, while her brain (visible through a cutaway skull) shows highlighted neural pathways in electric blue, illustrating the hormonal cascade being triggered—creating a visual bridge between scent detection and biological response.

facts.text: The loudest sound ever recorded was the 1883 Krakatoa volcanic eruption, which ruptured the eardrums of sailors 40 miles away and circled the entire Earth four times as a detectable atmospheric pressure wave. The shock wave was so powerful that it's estimated to have reached 310 decibels, far beyond the threshold where sound waves become lethal shock waves that can rupture organs.
facts.verification_note: The Krakatoa eruption of 1883 did rupture eardrums of sailors at that distance, the pressure wave circled Earth multiple times (recorded by barographs worldwide), and estimates of 310 dB are consistent with scientific literature, though the exact decibel level involves some uncertainty in measurement methodology.
facts.image_description: The illustration depicts a dramatic split-screen composition: the left half shows the catastrophic moment of Krakatoa's eruption with a towering column of ash and superheated gas exploding upward in violent reds, oranges, and deep blacks against a sickly yellow-green sky, while concentric rings of visible shock waves ripple outward like translucent amber halos. The right half presents a cross-section view of Earth from space, showing four distinct pale blue pressure wave bands encircling the globe like ethereal ribbons, with small sailing vessels dotting the ocean surface near the epicenter, their tiny scale emphasizing the eruption's incomprehensible power. The style blends photorealistic rendering with scientific diagram elements—including a decibel scale bar glowing ominously in deep red as it climbs past 300 dB, and subtle anatomical overlays showing human ear structures with stress indicators. Lightning bolts crackle through the ash cloud while the ocean surface below shows radiating tsunami rings, all rendered with sharp detail and dramatic chiaroscuro lighting that makes the scene feel both terrifyingly real and educational.

facts.text: Slime molds, which are single-celled organisms without brains, can solve complex mazes and recreate efficient transportation networks that mirror human-designed railway systems. When placed at food sources matching the locations of cities around Tokyo, the slime mold Physarum polycephalum grew a network nearly identical to the existing Tokyo rail system.
facts.verification_note: This claim accurately describes well-documented experiments published in peer-reviewed journals, particularly a 2010 Science paper by Tero et al., demonstrating that Physarum polycephalum can solve mazes and did recreate a network strikingly similar to Tokyo's rail system when oat flakes were placed at locations corresponding to cities around Tokyo.
facts.image_description: The illustration should be split into two mirrored halves: the left showing a translucent, bioluminescent yellow-gold Physarum polycephalum slime mold spreading across a dark petri dish, its veined network pulsing with an ethereal glow as it connects small oat flakes positioned like city nodes; the right half displaying the actual Tokyo rail system map with its iconic colored lines overlaid on a subtle geographic outline, with matching city positions highlighted. The composition should use a deep midnight blue background to make both networks pop dramatically, with the slime mold rendered in a semi-photorealistic style featuring visible protoplasmic streaming and delicate branching tendrils, while the rail map maintains clean, technical precision. Subtle golden connecting lines or dotted paths should bridge the two halves, emphasizing the remarkable similarity between the organic and engineered networks, with soft spotlighting creating a sense of scientific revelation and wonder.

facts.text: The Tunguska event of 1908 in Siberia flattened 80 million trees across 830 square miles, yet left no impact crater—scientists now believe an asteroid or comet exploded in the atmosphere with 1,000 times the force of the Hiroshima bomb, but never actually hit the ground.
facts.verification_note: The Tunguska event did flatten approximately 80 million trees over roughly 830 square miles with no crater, and scientific consensus attributes it to an airburst explosion of an asteroid or comet estimated at 10-15 megatons (approximately 1,000 times Hiroshima's yield) that detonated several kilometers above the ground.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a dramatic aerial view of the Siberian taiga at the moment of the Tunguska blast, showing a massive spherical shockwave of brilliant white-orange light expanding outward from a central point high in the atmosphere, with trees below radiating outward in a perfect butterfly pattern like fallen dominoes. The style should blend photorealistic detail with scientific diagram aesthetics—the foreground showing individual splintered trees lying parallel to each other, while the background fades into a cross-sectional view revealing the exploding asteroid or comet fragment as a glowing mass suspended miles above the earth's surface, with pressure wave lines illustrated in semi-transparent blue. The color palette should contrast the cold blue-grey of the Siberian dawn sky with the intense yellows and oranges of the atmospheric explosion, while smoke and vapor trails create dynamic diagonal lines that emphasize the violence of the blast. Include a small scale reference showing the 830-square-mile devastation zone from above, with the epicenter clearly marked but notably lacking any crater.

facts.text: When a glass breaks, the cracks propagate through the material at speeds up to 3,000 miles per hour—faster than a speeding bullet—and high-speed cameras reveal that the fracture creates a beautiful spiral pattern that mirrors the structure of galaxies and seashells due to the same mathematical principles governing both.
facts.verification_note: Crack propagation in glass does reach speeds around 3,000 mph (approximately half the speed of sound in glass), and fracture patterns do exhibit spiral formations governed by similar mathematical principles (like logarithmic spirals and fractal geometry) that appear in galaxies and shells, though the physical mechanisms differ.
facts.image_description: The illustration should capture a dramatic split-screen moment: the left side shows a high-speed photograph of a glass pane mid-shatter, with luminous cracks spiraling outward in a mesmerizing Fibonacci pattern, each fracture line glowing with electric blues and whites against the transparent glass, frozen at the exact millisecond of propagation. The right side mirrors this with a ethereal cosmic spiral—a galaxy whose arms echo the exact same mathematical curve—rendered in deep purples and star-studded whites, with a delicate nautilus shell superimposed at the center, its chambers following the identical logarithmic spiral. The composition should use a photorealistic style for the shattering glass with scientific precision, while the cosmic elements blend into a more dreamlike, slightly surreal treatment, connected by golden ratio guide lines that trace through both halves. Dramatic side-lighting should catch the glass fragments like prisms, creating rainbow refractions that bridge into the stellar light of the galaxy, while motion blur trails behind the crack tips suggest their bullet-speed velocity.

<svg width="800" height="600" viewBox="0 0 800 600" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <defs>
    <!-- Gradients for glass -->
    <radialGradient id="glassGrad" cx="30%" cy="30%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#ffffff;stop-opacity:0.9"/>
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#e0f4ff;stop-opacity:0.6"/>
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#b0d4e8;stop-opacity:0.3"/>
    </radialGradient>
    
    <!-- Gradient for glowing cracks -->
    <linearGradient id="crackGlow" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#00d4ff;stop-opacity:1"/>
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#0088ff;stop-opacity:0.9"/>
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#ffffff;stop-opacity:0.7"/>
    </linearGradient>
    
    <!-- Galaxy gradient -->
    <radialGradient id="galaxyCore" cx="50%" cy="50%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#ffffff;stop-opacity:1"/>
      <stop offset="20%" style="stop-color:#ffccff;stop-opacity:0.8"/>
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#8844ff;stop-opacity:0.6"/>
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#1a0033;stop-opacity:1"/>
    </radialGradient>
    
    <!-- Cosmic spiral gradient -->
    <linearGradient id="cosmicArm" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#6633cc;stop-opacity:0.8"/>
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#9966ff;stop-opacity:0.6"/>
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#cc99ff;stop-opacity:0.3"/>
    </linearGradient>
    
    <!-- Rainbow refraction -->
    <linearGradient id="rainbow" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#ff0066"/>
      <stop offset="20%" style="stop-color:#ff9900"/>
      <stop offset="40%" style="stop-color:#ffff00"/>
      <stop offset="60%" style="stop-color:#00ff88"/>
      <stop offset="80%" style="stop-color:#0088ff"/>
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#9900ff"/>
    </linearGradient>
    
    <!-- Glow filter -->
    <filter id="glow">
      <feGaussianBlur stdDeviation="3" result="coloredBlur"/>
      <feMerge>
        <feMergeNode in="coloredBlur"/>
        <feMergeNode in="SourceGraphic"/>
      </feMerge>
    </filter>
    
    <!-- Motion blur -->
    <filter id="motionBlur">
      <feGaussianBlur in="SourceGraphic" stdDeviation="2,0" />
    </filter>
  </defs>
  
  <!-- Background -->
  <rect width="400" height="600" fill="#1a1a2e"/>
  <rect x="400" width="400" height="600" fill="#0a0015"/>
  
  <!-- Left side: Shattering Glass -->
  <g id="glassPane">
    <!-- Glass surface -->
    <rect x="50" y="50" width="300" height="500" fill="url(#glassGrad)" opacity="0.7"/>
    
    <!-- Impact center -->
    <circle cx="200" cy="300" r="15" fill="#ffffff" opacity="0.9" filter="url(#glow)"/>
    
    <!-- Fibonacci spiral cracks - main spiral -->
    <path d="M 200 300 Q 210 290 220 285 Q 235 278 250 280 Q 270 283 285 295 Q 300 310 305 330 Q 308 355 300 375 Q 285 400 260 415 Q 230 428 195 425 Q 155 420 125 395 Q 95 365 85 325 Q 78 280 95 240 Q 118 195 160 170 Q 210 145 265 155" 
          fill="none" stroke="url(#crackGlow)" stroke-width="3" filter="url(#glow)"/>
    
    <!-- Secondary spiral arms -->
    <path d="M 200 300 Q 195 285 188 275 Q 178 260 165 252 Q 148 243 130 245 Q 110 248 95 260" 
          fill="none" stroke="url(#crackGlow)" stroke-width="2.5" filter="url(#glow)"/>
    
    <path d="M 200 300 Q 215 310 230 315 Q 248 322 265 322 Q 285 320 300 310" 
          fill="none" stroke="url(#crackGlow)" stroke-width="2.5" filter="url(#glow)"/>
    
    <path d="M 200 300 Q 190 315 180 332 Q 168 352 165 375 Q 163 400 170 420" 
          fill="none" stroke="url(#crackGlow)" stroke-width="2" filter="url(#glow)"/>
    
    <path d="M 200 300 Q 210 305 222 312 Q 238 322 250 338 Q 262 358 265 380" 
          fill="none" stroke="url(#crackGlow)" stroke-width="2" filter="url(#glow)"/>
    
    <!-- Radiating cracks -->
    <line x1="200" y1="300" x2="150" y2="200" stroke="#00d4ff" stroke-width="1.5" opacity="0.8" filter="url(#glow)"/>
    <line x1="200" y1="300" x2="280" y2="220" stroke="#0099ff" stroke-width="1.5" opacity="0.8" filter="url(#glow)"/>
    <line x1="200" y1="300" x2="120" y2="350" stroke="#00bbff" stroke-width="1.5" opacity="0.7" filter="url(#glow)"/>
    <line x1="200" y1="300" x2="310" y2="380" stroke="#00aaff" stroke-width="1.5" opacity="0.7" filter="url(#glow)"/>
    <line x1="200" y1="300" x2="180" y2="450" stroke="#0088ff" stroke-width="1.5" opacity="0.6" filter="url(#glow)"/>
    
    <!-- Glass fragments -->
    <polygon points="210,290 225,285 220,275" fill="#e0f4ff" opacity="0.6"/>

facts.text: When you get a sunburn, the damage to your skin cells triggers them to commit suicide through a process called apoptosis, and it's actually this mass cellular suicide—not the UV radiation itself—that causes the characteristic peeling days later.
facts.verification_note: UV radiation causes DNA damage in skin cells, triggering apoptosis (programmed cell death) as a protective mechanism, and the subsequent shedding of these dead cells is what causes the peeling observed several days after sunburn.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a cross-section of human skin in a semi-transparent, scientific style with glowing elements. The upper dermis shows clusters of sun-damaged cells in angry reds and oranges, with some cells illuminated in ethereal blue-white light as they undergo apoptosis—visualized as cells peacefully fragmenting into neat, membrane-bound packets. Above the skin surface, golden UV rays pierce downward like spears, while below, a "wave" of self-destructing cells creates a distinct separation layer shown in luminous purples and teals, with the topmost layer beginning to lift and curl away like peeling paint. The composition should contrast the chaotic initial UV damage (sharp, aggressive yellows and reds) with the orderly, almost beautiful process of programmed cell death (cool, bioluminescent blues), all rendered in a style blending medical textbook precision with an artistic, slightly ethereal quality that makes cellular death appear as an elegant protective mechanism.

facts.text: The Brontosaurus never actually went extinct—it was "extinct" from science for 112 years because paleontologists decided in 1903 that it was just a misidentified Apatosaurus, only to officially resurrect the genus in 2015 after discovering the skeletal differences were significant enough to warrant separate classification after all.
facts.verification_note: The Brontosaurus genus was indeed synonymized with Apatosaurus in 1903 by Elmer Riggs and reinstated as a valid separate genus in 2015 by Tschopp et al. based on comprehensive skeletal analysis showing sufficient morphological differences.
facts.image_description: The illustration depicts a majestic Brontosaurus emerging from translucent layers of aged, sepia-toned scientific manuscripts and faded taxonomic charts dated 1903-2015, as if breaking free from paper imprisonment. The dinosaur is rendered in rich, scientifically accurate detail with deep forest greens and earthy browns on its left side (representing its "Apatosaurus" period), transitioning to vibrant teals and warm ambers on its right side (its resurrection), while its long neck curves upward triumphantly toward golden afternoon light. The background features a split composition: the left shows ghostly, crossed-out skeletal diagrams and Victorian-era paleontology tools in muted grays, while the right displays modern 3D bone scans and digital measurements in crisp blues and whites, connected by floating vertebrae that shift subtly in shape between the two sides. Small details include a prominent "1903" date stamp dissolving into particles on one side and a glowing "2015" emerging on the other, with magnified callouts highlighting the crucial skeletal differences—particularly neck vertebrae and shoulder bones—that justified the genus's scientific

facts.text: The mantis shrimp can punch so fast that it creates cavitation bubbles in the water, which collapse with a flash of light and temperatures reaching 4,700°C—nearly as hot as the surface of the sun—stunning or killing prey even if the punch misses.
facts.verification_note: Mantis shrimp strikes do create cavitation bubbles that collapse producing sonoluminescence with temperatures around 4,700°C (comparable to the sun's surface at ~5,500°C), generating secondary shockwaves that can stun prey independently of direct contact.
facts.image_description: A split-second underwater scene captures a vibrant peacock mantis shrimp mid-strike, its club-like appendage blurred with motion as it hammers toward a small crab. The water around the impact point erupts with translucent cavitation bubbles rendered in luminous blues and whites, with several bubbles collapsing in brilliant flashes of orange-white light that illuminate the surrounding murky green water. The illustration uses a photorealistic style with scientific diagram overlays—temperature readings glowing in amber text near the light bursts, and motion lines tracking the appendage's 50mph trajectory. The mantis shrimp itself displays its characteristic iridescent greens, blues, and reds in sharp detail against the softer, motion-blurred background, while the startled prey is caught frozen in the supernatural glow of the miniature underwater explosions.

facts.text: The Turritopsis dohrnii jellyfish can reverse its aging process and revert back to its polyp stage after reaching sexual maturity, essentially making it biologically immortal. When injured or stressed, it transforms all its existing cells into a younger state through a process called transdifferentiation, allowing it to bypass death and restart its life cycle indefinitely.
facts.verification_note: Turritopsis dohrnii can indeed reverse its life cycle through transdifferentiation, reverting from its medusa stage back to a polyp stage in response to stress or injury, which theoretically allows it to bypass natural death indefinitely, though it can still die from predation or disease.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict the Turritopsis dohrnii's life cycle as a circular diagram against a deep ocean blue gradient background, with bioluminescent lighting effects. At the top, show a mature, translucent bell-shaped jellyfish with delicate trailing tentacles in pale pink and cream tones, its body glowing from within. A curved arrow should lead clockwise downward to show the transformation sequence: the jellyfish gradually shrinking and simplifying into a small, polyp form attached to a rock, with cellular detail visible through semi-transparent tissue showing the transdifferentiation process in golden and amber highlights. The style should blend scientific accuracy with ethereal beauty—photorealistic textures combined with subtle artistic enhancement, featuring cross-sections revealing the cellular metamorphosis, tiny DNA helixes, and regenerating cells illustrated as glowing particles flowing backward through the cycle, emphasizing the "reverse aging" phenomenon with a counterclockwise infinity symbol subtly integrated into the composition.
facts.image_svg:
<svg width="800" height="600" viewBox="0 0 800 600" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <defs>
    <radialGradient id="oceanBg" cx="50%" cy="50%" r="70%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#1a4d7a;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#0d2f4f;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#061829;stop-opacity:1" />
    </radialGradient>
    
    <radialGradient id="jellyfishGlow" cx="50%" cy="40%" r="60%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#fff5f0;stop-opacity:0.9" />
      <stop offset="40%" style="stop-color:#ffd4c8;stop-opacity:0.6" />
      <stop offset="70%" style="stop-color:#ffb8a8;stop-opacity:0.3" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#ff9999;stop-opacity:0" />
    </radialGradient>
    
    <radialGradient id="polypGlow" cx="50%" cy="50%" r="50%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#ffd700;stop-opacity:0.8" />
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#ffb347;stop-opacity:0.4" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#ff8c00;stop-opacity:0" />
    </radialGradient>
    
    <linearGradient id="cellGradient" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#ffd700;stop-opacity:0.7" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#ff6347;stop-opacity:0.7" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <filter id="glow">
      <feGaussianBlur stdDeviation="4" result="coloredBlur"/>
      <feMerge>
        <feMergeNode in="coloredBlur"/>
        <feMergeNode in="SourceGraphic"/>
      </feMerge>
    </filter>
    
    <filter id="softGlow">
      <feGaussianBlur stdDeviation="2" result="coloredBlur"/>
      <feMerge>
        <feMergeNode in="coloredBlur"/>
        <feMergeNode in="SourceGraphic"/>
      </feMerge>
    </filter>
  </defs>
  
  <rect width="800" height="600" fill="url(#oceanBg)"/>
  
  <!-- Bioluminescent particles -->
  <circle cx="100" cy="150" r="2" fill="#4dd0e1" opacity="0.6">
    <animate attributeName="opacity" values="0.3;0.8;0.3" dur="3s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
  </circle>
  <circle cx="700" cy="200" r="1.5" fill="#80deea" opacity="0.5">
    <animate attributeName="opacity" values="0.2;0.7;0.2" dur="4s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
  </circle>
  <circle cx="150" cy="450" r="2.5" fill="#4dd0e1" opacity="0.7">
    <animate attributeName="opacity" values="0.4;0.9;0.4" dur="2.5s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
  </circle>
  <circle cx="650" cy="480" r="1.8" fill="#80deea" opacity="0.6">
    <animate attributeName="opacity" values="0.3;0.8;0.3" dur="3.5s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
  </circle>
  
  <!-- Infinity symbol (subtle) -->
  <path d="M 300 300 Q 250 250 200 300 Q 150 350 200 400 Q 250 450 300 400 Q 350 350 400 300 Q 450 250 500 300 Q 550 350 500 400 Q 450 450 400 400 Q 350 350 300 300" 
        fill="none" stroke="#1a4d7a" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.3"/>
  
  <!-- Circular arrow path (clockwise) -->
  <path id="cycleArrow" d="M 400 100 A 180 180 0 1 1 399 100" fill="none" stroke="#4dd0e1" stroke-width="3" opacity="0.4" stroke-dasharray="10,5"/>
  
  <!-- Counter-clockwise flow indicators -->
  <g opacity="0.5">
    <path d="M 580 200 Q 600 220 590 240" fill="none" stroke="#ffd700" stroke-width="2" marker-end="url(#arrowhead)">
      <animate attributeName="stroke-opacity" values="0.3;0.8;0.3" dur="2s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
    </path>
    <path d="M 550 450 Q 530 470 510 460" fill="none" stroke="#ffd700" stroke-width="2">
      <animate attributeName="stroke-opacity" values="0.3;0.8;0.3" dur="2s" begin="0.5s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
    </path>
    <path d="M 220 450 Q 200 470 180 460" fill="none" stroke="#ffd700" stroke-width="2">
      <animate attributeName="stroke-opacity" values="0.3;0.8;0.3" dur="2s" begin="1s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
    </path>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Mature Jellyfish (top) -->
  <g transform="translate(400, 120)">
    <!-- Glow effect -->
    <ellipse cx="0" cy="0" rx="70" ry="50" fill="url(#jellyfishGlow)" opacity="0.6" filter="url(#glow)"/>
    
    <!-- Bell body -->
    <ellipse cx="0" cy="0" rx="60" ry="45" fill="#ffe6e0" opacity="0.8" stroke="#ffc4b8" stroke-width="2"/>
    <ellipse cx="0" cy="0" rx="50" ry="38" fill="#fff5f0" opacity="0.6"/>
    <ellipse cx="0" cy="-5" rx="35" ry="25" fill="#ffffff" opacity="0.5"/>
    
    <!-- Inner structures -->
    <ellipse cx="0" cy="5" rx="30" ry="20" fill="#ffd4c8" opacity="0.4"/>
    <path d="M -20 0 Q 0 15 20 0" fill="none" stroke="#ffb8a8" stroke-width="1.5" opacity="0.6"/>
    <path d="M -15 -10 Q 0 0 15 -10" fill="none" stroke="#ffb8a8" stroke-width="1.5" opacity="0.6"/>
    
    <!-- Tentacles -->
    <g opacity="0.7">
      <path d="M -40 35 Q -45 80 -42 130" fill="none" stroke="#ffc4b8" stroke-width="3">
        <animate attributeName="d" values="M -40 35 Q -45 80 -42 130;M -40 35 Q -48 80 -45 130;M -40 35 Q -45 80 -42 130" dur="4s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
      </path>
      <path d="M -20 40 Q -22 85 -20 135" fill="none" stroke="#ffd4c8" stroke-width="2.5">
        <animate attributeName="d" values="M -20 40 Q -22 85 -20 135;M -20 40 Q -25 85 -23 135;M -20 40 Q -22 85 -20 135" dur="3.5s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
      </path>
      <path d="M 0 42 Q 0 90 2 140" fill="none" stroke="#ffe6e0" stroke-width="2">
        <animate attributeName="d" values="M 0 42 Q 0 90 2 140;M 0 42 Q -3 90 -1 140;M 0 42 Q 0 90 2 140" dur="4.5s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
      </path>
      <path d="M 20 40 Q 22 85 20 135" fill="none" stroke="#ffd4c8" stroke-width="2.5">
        <animate attributeName="d" values="M 20 40 Q 22 85 20 135;M 20 40 Q 25 85 23 135;M 20 40 Q 22 85 20 135" dur="3.8s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
      </path>
      <path d="M 40 35 Q 45 80 42 130" fill="none" stroke="#ffc4b8" stroke-width="3">
        <animate attributeName="d" values="M 40 35 Q 45 80 42 130;M 40 35 Q 48 80 45 130;M 40 35 Q 45 80 42 130" dur="4.2s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
      </path>
    </g>
    
    <!-- DNA helix particles -->
    <circle cx="-15" cy="0" r="2" fill="#ffd700" opacity="0.8" filter="url(#softGlow)">
      <animate attributeName="cy" values="0;10;0" dur="2s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
    </circle>
    <circle cx="15" cy="5" r="2" fill="#ffb347" opacity="0.8" filter="url(#softGlow)">
      <animate attributeName="cy" values="5;15;5" dur="2s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
    </circle>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Transition stage 1 (right side) -->
  <g transform="translate(600, 300)">
    <ellipse cx="0" cy="0" rx="35" ry="28" fill="#ffd4c8" opacity="0.7" stroke="#ffb8a8" stroke-width="1.5"/>
    <ellipse cx="0" cy="0" rx="25" ry="20" fill="#ffe6e0" opacity="0.6"/>
    
    <!-- Shorter tentacles -->
    <path d="M -20 22 Q -22 40 -20 55" fill="none" stroke="#ffc4b8" stroke-width="2.5" opacity="0.6"/>
    <path d="M 0 25 Q 0 45 2 60" fill="none" stroke="#ffd4c8" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.6"/>
    <path d="M 20 22 Q 22 40 20 55" fill="none" stroke="#ffc4b8" stroke-width="2.5" opacity="0.6"/>
    
    <!-- Cellular detail -->
    <circle cx="-8" cy="0" r="3" fill="#ffd700" opacity="0.6"/>
    <circle cx="8" cy="-3" r="3" fill="#ffb347" opacity="0.6"/>
    <circle cx="0" cy="8" r="2.5" fill="#ff8c00" opacity="0.5"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Transition stage 2 (bottom right) -->
  <g transform="translate(520, 450)">
    <ellipse cx="0" cy="0" rx="25" ry="30" fill="#ffb8a8" opacity="0.7" stroke="#ff9999" stroke-width="1.5"/>
    <ellipse cx="0" cy="5" rx="18" ry="22" fill="#ffd4c8" opacity="0.6"/>
    
    <!-- Very short tentacles -->
    <path d="M -12 25 Q -13 32 -12 38" fill="none" stroke="#ffc4b8" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.5"/>
    <path d="M 12 25 Q 13 32 12 38" fill="none" stroke="#ffc4b8" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.5"/>
    
    <!-- Transdifferentiation particles -->
    <circle cx="-5" cy="0" r="2.5" fill="url(#cellGradient)" opacity="0.7" filter="url(#softGlow)">
      <animate attributeName="r" values="2.5;3.5;2.5" dur="1.5s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
    </circle>
    <circle cx="5" cy="5" r="2" fill="url(#cellGradient)" opacity="0.7" filter="url(#softGlow)">
      <animate attributeName="r" values="2;3;2" dur="1.8s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
    </circle>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Polyp stage (bottom) -->
  <g transform="translate(400, 500)">
    <!-- Rock base -->
    <ellipse cx="0" cy="30" rx="50" ry="15" fill="#4a5568" opacity="0.6"/>
    <path d="M -40 30 Q -30 25 -20 28 Q -10 32 0 28 Q 10 24 20 28 Q 30 32 40 30" fill="#5a6978" opacity="0.5"/>
    
    <!-- Glow around polyp -->
    <ellipse cx="0" cy="0" rx="30" ry="35" fill="url(#polypGlow)" opacity="0.5" filter="url(#glow)"/>
    
    <!-- Polyp body -->
    <path d="M -15 25 L -12 5 Q -12 -5 -8 -10 L 0 -15 L 8 -10 Q 12 -5 12 5 L 15 25 Z" 
          fill="#ffd4c8" opacity="0.8" stroke="#ffb347" stroke-width="1.5"/>
    <path d="M -10 25 L -8 8 Q -8 0 -5 -5 L 0 -8 L 5 -5 Q 8 0 8 8 L 10 25 Z" 
          fill="#ffe6e0" opacity="0.7"/>
    
    <!-- Oral disc with tentacles -->
    <circle cx="0" cy="-15" r="8" fill="#ffb8a8" opacity="0.7"/>
    <g opacity="0.6">
      <line x1="0" y1="-15" x2="-8" y2="-25" stroke="#ffc4b8" stroke-width="1.5"/>
      <line x1="0" y1="-15" x2="-4" y2="-26" stroke="#ffd4c8" stroke-width="1.5"/>
      <line x1="0" y1="-15" x2="0" y2="-27" stroke="#ffe6e0" stroke-width="1.5"/>
      <line x1="0" y1="-15" x2="4" y2="-26" stroke="#ffd4c8" stroke-width="1.5"/>
      <line x1="0" y1="-15" x2="8" y2="-25" stroke="#ffc4b8" stroke-width="1.5"/>
    </g>
    
    <!-- Internal cellular structure -->
    <circle cx="-4" cy="5" r="3" fill="#ffd700" opacity="0.7" filter="url(#softGlow)">
      <animate attributeName="opacity" values="0.5;0.9;0.5" dur="2s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
    </circle>
    <circle cx="4" cy="8" r="2.5" fill="#ffb347" opacity="0.7" filter="url(#softGlow)">
      <animate attributeName="opacity" values="0.5;0.9;0.5" dur="2.2s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
    </circle>
    <circle cx="0" cy="15" r="2" fill="#ff8c00" opacity="0.6" filter="url(#softGlow)">
      <animate attributeName="opacity" values="0.4;0.8;0.4" dur="1.8s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
    </circle>
    
    <!-- DNA helix representation -->
    <g opacity="0.5">
      <circle cx="-6" cy="0" r="1.5" fill="#ffd700">
        <animate attributeName="cy" values="0;10;20" dur="3s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
      </circle>
      <circle cx="6" cy="10" r="1.5" fill="#ffb347">
        <animate attributeName="cy" values="10;20;0" dur="3s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
      </circle>
    </g>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Transition stage 3 (left side bottom) -->
  <g transform="translate(280, 450)">
    <ellipse cx="0" cy="0" rx="20" ry="25" fill="#ffc4b8" opacity="0.7" stroke="#ffb347" stroke-width="1.5"/>
    <path d="M -8 20 L -6 5 Q -6 -5 0 -10 L 6 5 L 8 20 Z" fill="#ffd4c8" opacity="0.6"/>
    
    <!-- Regenerating cells -->
    <circle cx="-4" cy="0" r="2" fill="#ffd700" opacity="0.8" filter="url(#softGlow)">
      <animate attributeName="r" values="2;3;2" dur="1.5s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
      <animate attributeName="opacity" values="0.6;1;0.6" dur="1.5s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
    </circle>
    <circle cx="4" cy="-3" r="2" fill="#ffb347" opacity="0.8" filter="url(#softGlow)">
      <animate attributeName="r" values="2;3;2" dur="1.7s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
      <animate attributeName="opacity" values="0.6;1;0.6" dur="1.7s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
    </circle>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Transition stage 4 (left side) -->
  <g transform="translate(200, 300)">
    <ellipse cx="0" cy="0" rx="30" ry="25" fill="#ffe6e0" opacity="0.7" stroke="#ffd4c8" stroke-width="1.5"/>
    <ellipse cx="0" cy="-5" rx="20" ry="15" fill="#fff5f0" opacity="0.6"/>
    
    <!-- Emerging tentacles -->
    <path d="M -15 20 Q -16 30 -15 40" fill="none" stroke="#ffc4b8" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.5"/>
    <path d="M 0 22 Q 0 32 1 42" fill="none" stroke="#ffd4c8" stroke-width="1.5" opacity="0.5"/>
    <path d="M 15 20 Q 16 30 15 40" fill="none" stroke="#ffc4b8" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.5"/>
    
    <!-- Glowing particles showing reverse aging -->
    <circle cx="-6" cy="-2" r="2.5" fill="#ffd700" opacity="0.8" filter="url(#softGlow)">
      <animate attributeName="cy" values="-2;3;-2" dur="2s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
      <animate attributeName="opacity" values="0.5;1;0.5" dur="2s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
    </circle>
    <circle cx="6" cy="2" r="2.5" fill="#ffb347" opacity="0.8" filter="url(#softGlow)">
      <animate attributeName="cy" values="2;7;2" dur="2.2s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
      <animate attributeName="opacity" values="0.5;1;0.5" dur="2.2s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
    </circle>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Flowing regenerating particles (showing reverse cycle) -->
  <g opacity="0.6">
    <circle cx="500" cy="480" r="3" fill="#ffd700" filter="url(#softGlow)">
      <animateMotion path="M 0 0 Q -50 -30 -100 -60 Q -150 -90 -200 -120" dur="4s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
      <animate attributeName="opacity" values="0;1;0" dur="4s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
    </circle>
    <circle cx="520" cy="470" r="2.5" fill="#ffb347" filter="url(#softGlow)">
      <animateMotion path="M 0 0 Q -60 -35 -120 -70 Q -180 -105 -240 -140" dur="4.5s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
      <animate attributeName="opacity" values="0;1;0" dur="4.5s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
    </circle>
    <circle cx="300" cy="480" r="3" fill="#ff8c00" filter="url(#softGlow)">
      <animateMotion path="M 0 0 Q -20 -40 -40 -80 Q -60 -120 -80 -160" dur="4.2s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
      <animate attributeName="opacity" values="0;1;0" dur="4.2s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
    </circle>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Additional ambient bioluminescent particles -->
  <g opacity="0.4">
    <circle cx="250" cy="250" r="1.5" fill="#80deea">
      <animate attributeName="opacity" values="0.2;0.6;0.2" dur="3s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
    </circle>
    <circle cx="550" cy="350" r="2" fill="#4dd0e1">
      <animate attributeName="opacity" values="0.3;0.7;0.3" dur="2.8s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
    </circle>
    <circle cx="350" cy="200" r="1.8" fill="#80deea">
      <animate attributeName="opacity" values="0.2;0.6;0.2" dur="3.3s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
    </circle>
    <circle cx="450" cy="400" r="1.5" fill="#4dd0e1">
      <animate attributeName="opacity" values="0.3;0.7;0.3" dur="2.5s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
    </circle>
  </g>
</svg>

facts.text: Bananas are naturally radioactive because they contain potassium-40, and eating one exposes you to about 0.1 microsieverts of radiation—so much so that truckloads of bananas can trigger radiation alarms at ports designed to detect smuggled nuclear materials.
facts.verification_note: Bananas do contain potassium-40 which makes them radioactive at approximately 0.1 microsieverts per banana, and large shipments have indeed triggered radiation portal monitors at ports and border crossings.
facts.image_description: A split-scene illustration in a vibrant, modern infographic style: On the left, a glowing yellow banana sits on a dark navy background, with luminescent green particles and atomic symbols (specifically K-40) radiating outward in concentric circles, creating an ethereal aura around the fruit. On the right, a large shipping truck loaded with banana crates approaches a red-and-white striped port security gate, where a startled customs officer watches a radiation detection monitor flash red warning lights and display a digital readout. The color palette contrasts warm yellows and oranges for the radioactive glow against cool blues and grays for the industrial port setting, with strategic highlighting to emphasize the connection between the innocent-looking fruit and the high-tech security equipment, while small floating text callouts show "K-40" and "0.1 μSv" near the banana.

facts.text: The fungus *Ophiocordyceps unilateralis* infects carpenter ants and hijacks their brains, compelling them to climb to a precise height and location with optimal temperature and humidity before clamping their jaws onto a leaf in a "death grip." The fungus then kills the ant and sprouts a fruiting body from its head to spread spores to other ants below.
facts.verification_note: This accurately describes the documented parasitic behavior of Ophiocordyceps unilateralis, including the manipulation of ant behavior to optimal environmental conditions, the death grip on vegetation, and the subsequent fruiting body emergence for spore dispersal.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a cross-section view of a rainforest understory in rich, saturated greens and earth tones, with dappled golden sunlight filtering through the canopy. In the foreground, a carpenter ant clings to the underside of a glossy leaf with its mandibles locked in the characteristic death grip, its exoskeleton rendered in deep amber and black with a semi-translucent quality revealing thread-like fungal mycelia branching through its body in ghostly white and pale orange. A dark, elongated fruiting body erupts dramatically from the ant's head like a twisted horn, textured with tiny spore-releasing structures visible under scientific magnification detail. The style should blend photorealistic macro photography with scientific illustration, showing both the haunting beauty and precise biological horror of the parasitic relationship, with additional infected ants visible on leaves below in softer focus, creating a sense of the fungus's methodical spread through the colony.

    <!-- Antennae -->

    <path d="M 390 322 L 387 325" stroke="#2d1800" stroke-width="2.5" stroke-linecap="round"/>

facts.text: Neutron stars are so dense that a teaspoon of their material would weigh about 6 billion tons on Earth—as much as all of humanity combined. These collapsed stellar cores spin up to 716 times per second while possessing a gravitational pull so intense that light bends visibly around them.
facts.verification_note: All three claims are scientifically accurate: neutron star density is approximately 4×10^17 kg/m³ (making a teaspoon weigh roughly 6 billion tons), the fastest observed pulsar (PSR J1748-2446ad) rotates 716 times per second, and their intense gravity does cause observable gravitational lensing of light.
facts.image_description: The illustration shows a split composition: on the left, a glowing teaspoon hovers against the black void of space, filled with swirling, impossibly dense neutron-degenerate matter that glows with an otherworldly blue-white luminescence and creates visible gravitational lensing that warps the starfield behind it into curved arcs. On the right side, for scale comparison, a translucent silhouette of Earth appears with ghostly representations of humanity's 8 billion people rendered as tiny points of light across its surface, connected by delicate golden threads to emphasize their collective mass equals just one teaspoon's worth. The neutron star itself dominates the background—a rapidly spinning sphere with magnetic field lines rendered in electric purple and cyan, creating a pulsar lighthouse effect with beams of radiation, while motion blur streaks suggest its incomprehensible 716-rotations-per-second spin in a photorealistic yet dramatic scientific illustration style with deep space blacks punctuated by vivid, high-contrast colors.

facts.text: When you die, your body's enzymes begin to digest you from the inside out in a process called autolysis, but your hair and nails don't actually keep growing—the skin around them simply dehydrates and retracts, creating the illusion of growth.
facts.verification_note: Autolysis does occur after death as cellular enzymes break down tissues, and the appearance of hair/nail growth is indeed caused by skin dehydration and retraction rather than actual growth, as these processes require metabolic activity that ceases at death.
facts.image_description: A split-panel scientific illustration in muted, clinical tones of blue-grey and pale flesh: the left side shows a cross-sectional view of human skin in vibrant health with clearly labeled hair follicles and nail beds surrounded by plump, hydrated tissue rendered in soft pinks and creams, while the right side depicts the same structures post-mortem where the surrounding tissue has visibly contracted and darkened to a dusky purple-grey, making the hair and nails appear longer by contrast. Delicate arrows and dotted lines highlight the retracting skin tissue, with translucent overlays showing enzyme activity as subtle golden-amber wisps breaking down cellular structures from within. The style blends medical textbook precision with a touch of ethereal beauty, using dramatic side-lighting that casts the living side in warm light and the deceased side in cool shadows, while maintaining scientific accuracy and anatomical detail down to individual skin cells and collagen fibers.

<svg width="800" height="600" viewBox="0 0 800 600" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">

  <!-- Hair follicle - appearing longer -->

  <circle cx="600" cy="380" r="11" fill="url(#enzymeGlow)" filter="url(#glow)"/>
  
  <!-- Enzyme particles -->
  <path d="M 575 295 Q 580 300 585 295" stroke="#FDB462" stroke-width="1.5" fill="none" opacity="0.6"/>

  <path d="M 555 355 Q 560 360 565 355" stroke="#FDB462" stroke-width="1.5" fill="none" opacity="0.6"/>
  
  <!-- Cell structures - degraded -->

  <circle cx="630" cy="320" r="8" fill="#7A6D8A" opacity="0.4"/>
  <circle cx="660" cy="360" r="7" fill="#7A6D8A" opacity="0.4"/>
  
  <!-- Retraction arrows on right -->
  <path d="M 480 250 L 500 270" stroke="#9CA3AF" stroke-width="2" fill="none" marker-end="url(#arrowhead)"/>
  <path d="M 480 350 L 500 330" stroke="#9CA3AF" stroke-width="2" fill="none" marker-end="url(#arrowhead)"/>
  <path d="M 720 280 L 700 300" stroke="#9CA3AF" stroke-width="2" fill="none" marker-end="url(#arrowhead)"/>
  <path d="M 720 380 L 700 360" stroke="#9CA3AF" stroke-width="2" fill="none" marker-end="url(#arrowhead)"/>
  
  <!-- Dotted lines showing retraction -->
  <line x1="150" y1="180" x2="550" y2="200" stroke="#718096" stroke-width="1" stroke-dasharray="2,4" opacity="0.5"/>

</svg>

facts.text: Tardigrades, microscopic eight-legged creatures, can survive being frozen to near absolute zero (-272°C), boiled at 150°C, exposed to the vacuum of space, and blasted with radiation 1,000 times the lethal dose for humans. When conditions become unbearable, they expel nearly all water from their bodies, retract their legs, and enter a death-like state called cryptobiosis where they can remain for decades before springing back to life when rehydrated.
facts.verification_note: All stated claims about tardigrade extremotolerance are well-documented in scientific literature, including survival at near absolute zero temperatures, high heat tolerance, vacuum exposure in space experiments, extreme radiation resistance (though some sources cite even higher tolerances), and cryptobiosis lasting decades with successful rehydration.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a split-scene composition showing a magnified tardigrade as the central figure—a translucent, bear-like creature with eight stubby legs tipped with claws, rendered in luminous blues and pale golds against a dark cosmic background. The left side shows the tardigrade in its active, hydrated state with visible internal structures and a slight glow, while the right side shows it in its cryptobiotic "tun" form—a shrunken, barrel-shaped husk with retracted legs, appearing crystalline and frosted. Surrounding both forms are visual representations of extreme conditions: ice crystals and absolute-zero temperature readings, flames and heat waves, the star-studded void of space, and stylized radiation symbols with dangerous orange-yellow emanations, all rendered in a semi-realistic scientific illustration style with dramatic lighting that emphasizes the tardigrade's otherworldly resilience. Small water droplets should be shown being expelled from and reabsorbed into the creature, with delicate arrows indicating the transformation process between states.
