<svg width="800" height="600" viewBox="0 0 800 600" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <defs>
    <radialGradient id="cosmicBg" cx="50%" cy="50%" r="50%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#0a0e27;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#000000;stop-opacity:1" />
    </radialGradient>
    
    <radialGradient id="tardigradeGlow" cx="50%" cy="50%" r="50%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#4dd5ff;stop-opacity:0.8" />
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#2196f3;stop-opacity:0.6" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#1565c0;stop-opacity:0.3" />
    </radialGradient>
    
    <radialGradient id="tunGlow" cx="50%" cy="50%" r="50%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#b8d4e8;stop-opacity:0.6" />
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#7ba5c4;stop-opacity:0.4" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#4a7a9e;stop-opacity:0.2" />
    </radialGradient>
    
    <linearGradient id="fireGrad" x1="0%" y1="100%" x2="0%" y2="0%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#ff4500;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#ff8c00;stop-opacity:0.8" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#ffd700;stop-opacity:0.6" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <radialGradient id="radiationGlow" cx="50%" cy="50%" r="50%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#ffeb3b;stop-opacity:0.9" />
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#ff9800;stop-opacity:0.6" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#ff5722;stop-opacity:0.3" />
    </radialGradient>
    
    <filter id="glow">
      <feGaussianBlur stdDeviation="4" result="coloredBlur"/>
      <feMerge>
        <feMergeNode in="coloredBlur"/>
        <feMergeNode in="SourceGraphic"/>
      </feMerge>
    </filter>
    
    <filter id="frost">
      <feTurbulence type="fractalNoise" baseFrequency="0.9" numOctaves="4" result="noise"/>
      <feColorMatrix in="noise" type="saturate" values="0"/>
      <feComponentTransfer>
        <feFuncA type="discrete" tableValues="0 0.3 0.5 0.7"/>
      </feComponentTransfer>
    </filter>
  </defs>
  
  <!-- Cosmic Background -->
  <rect width="800" height="600" fill="url(#cosmicBg)"/>
  
  <!-- Stars -->
  <circle cx="100" cy="80" r="1.5" fill="#ffffff" opacity="0.8"/>
  <circle cx="150" cy="120" r="1" fill="#ffffff" opacity="0.6"/>
  <circle cx="680" cy="90" r="1.5" fill="#ffffff" opacity="0.9"/>
  <circle cx="720" cy="150" r="1" fill="#ffffff" opacity="0.7"/>
  <circle cx="650" cy="200" r="1.2" fill="#ffffff" opacity="0.8"/>
  <circle cx="130" cy="500" r="1" fill="#ffffff" opacity="0.6"/>
  <circle cx="700" cy="480" r="1.5" fill="#ffffff" opacity="0.8"/>
  <circle cx="50" cy="300" r="1.2" fill="#ffffff" opacity="0.7"/>
  <circle cx="750" cy="350" r="1" fill="#ffffff" opacity="0.6"/>
  
  <!-- Ice Crystals (Left Side) -->
  <g opacity="0.7">
    <path d="M 100 200 L 110 210 L 100 220 L 90 210 Z" fill="#b3e5fc" opacity="0.6"/>
    <path d="M 100 200 L 100 230" stroke="#81d4fa" stroke-width="1" opacity="0.8"/>
    <path d="M 85 210 L 115 210" stroke="#81d4fa" stroke-width="1" opacity="0.8"/>
    <path d="M 90 202 L 110 218" stroke="#81d4fa" stroke-width="1" opacity="0.8"/>
    <path d="M 110 202 L 90 218" stroke="#81d4fa" stroke-width="1" opacity="0.8"/>
    
    <path d="M 150 450 L 160 460 L 150 470 L 140 460 Z" fill="#b3e5fc" opacity="0.6"/>
    <path d="M 150 450 L 150 480" stroke="#81d4fa" stroke-width="1" opacity="0.8"/>
    <path d="M 135 460 L 165 460" stroke="#81d4fa" stroke-width="1" opacity="0.8"/>
    
    <path d="M 80 350 L 90 360 L 80 370 L 70 360 Z" fill="#b3e5fc" opacity="0.6"/>
    <path d="M 80 350 L 80 380" stroke="#81d4fa" stroke-width="1" opacity="0.8"/>
    <path d="M 65 360 L 95 360" stroke="#81d4fa" stroke-width="1" opacity="0.8"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Flames (Right Side) -->
  <g opacity="0.7">
    <path d="M 700 420 Q 695 400 700 380 Q 705 400 700 420 Z" fill="url(#fireGrad)" opacity="0.7"/>
    <path d="M 710 425 Q 707 410 710 395 Q 713 410 710 425 Z" fill="url(#fireGrad)" opacity="0.6"/>
    <path d="M 690 423 Q 687 408 690 393 Q 693 408 690 423 Z" fill="url(#fireGrad)" opacity="0.6"/>
    
    <path d="M 650 180 Q 645 165 650 150 Q 655 165 650 180 Z" fill="url(#fireGrad)" opacity="0.7"/>
    <path d="M 660 183 Q 657 170 660 157 Q 663 170 660 183 Z" fill="url(#fireGrad)" opacity="0.6"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Radiation Symbols (Right Side) -->
  <g opacity="0.8">
    <circle cx="720" cy="300" r="25" fill="url(#radiationGlow)" opacity="0.3"/>
    <path d="M 720 280 L 720 290 M 720 310 L 720 320 M 708 288 L 714 294 M 726 306 L 732 312 M 732 288 L 726 294 M 714 306 L 708 312" 
          stroke="#ff9800" stroke-width="3" fill="none"/>
    <circle cx="720" cy="300" r="5" fill="#ffeb3b"/>
    
    <circle cx="680" cy="500" r="20" fill="url(#radiationGlow)" opacity="0.3"/>
    <path d="M 680 485 L 680 492 M 680 508 L 680 515 M 671 490 L 675 495 M 685 505 L 689 510 M 689 490 L 685 495 M 675 505 L 671 510" 
          stroke="#ff9800" stroke-width="2.5" fill="none"/>
    <circle cx="680" cy="500" r="4" fill="#ffeb3b"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Space Void Indicators -->
  <rect x="50" y="50" width="80" height="80" fill="none" stroke="#4a148c" stroke-width="2" stroke-dasharray="5,5" opacity="0.5"/>
  <rect x="670" y="50" width="80" height="80" fill="none" stroke="#4a148c" stroke-width="2" stroke-dasharray="5,5" opacity="0.5"/>
  
  <!-- LEFT SIDE: Active Tardigrade -->
  <g transform="translate(200, 280)">
    <!-- Glow -->
    <ellipse cx="0" cy="0" rx="90" ry="60" fill="url(#tardigradeGlow)" filter="url(#glow)" opacity="0.6"/>
    
    <!-- Body -->
    <ellipse cx="0" cy="0" rx="70" ry="45" fill="#4dd5ff" opacity="0.7" stroke="#2196f3" stroke-width="2"/>
    
    <!-- Head -->
    <ellipse cx="-50" cy="-5" rx="30" ry="28" fill="#5de2ff" opacity="0.75" stroke="#2196f3" stroke-width="2"/>
    
    <!-- Mouth parts -->
    <circle cx="-65" cy="-5" r="8" fill="#1976d2" opacity="0.6"/>
    <path d="M -65 -5 L -75 -8 M -65 -5 L -75 -2" stroke="#1565c0" stroke-width="2" fill="none"/>
    
    <!-- Internal structures -->
    <ellipse cx="-20" cy="0" rx="15" ry="10" fill="#ffd54f" opacity="0.5"/>
    <ellipse cx="10" cy="-5" rx="12" ry="8" fill="#ffd54f" opacity="0.5"/>
    <ellipse cx="25" cy="5" rx="10" ry="7" fill="#ffd54f" opacity="0.5"/>
    
    <!-- Legs (4 pairs, 8 total) -->
    <!-- Left side legs -->
    <g opacity="0.8">
      <path d="M -40 20 Q -45 35 -40 45 L -38 48" stroke="#2196f3" stroke-width="4" fill="none" stroke-linecap="round"/>
      <circle cx="-38" cy="48" r="3" fill="#1565c0"/>
      
      <path d="M -15 25 Q -20 40 -15 50 L -13 53" stroke="#2196f3" stroke-width="4" fill="none" stroke-linecap="round"/>
      <circle cx="-13" cy="53" r="3" fill="#1565c0"/>
      
      <path d="M 10 28 Q 5 43 10 53 L 12 56" stroke="#2196f3" stroke-width="4" fill="none" stroke-linecap="round"/>
      <circle cx="12" cy="56" r="3" fill="#1565c0"/>
      
      <path d="M 35 25 Q 30 40 35 50 L 37 53" stroke="#2196f3" stroke-width="4" fill="none" stroke-linecap="round"/>
      <circle cx="37" cy="53" r="3" fill="#1565c0"/>
      
      <!-- Right side legs -->
      <path d="M -40 -20 Q -45 -35 -40 -45 L -38 -48" stroke="#2196f3" stroke-width="4" fill="none" stroke-linecap="round"/>
      <circle cx="-38" cy="-48" r="3" fill="#1565c0"/>
      
      <path d="M -15 -25 Q -20 -40 -15 -50 L -13 -53" stroke="#2196f3" stroke-width="4" fill="none" stroke-linecap="round"/>
      <circle cx="-13" cy="-53" r="3" fill="#1565c0"/>
      
      <path d="M 10 -28 Q 5 -43 10 -53 L 12 -56" stroke="#2196f3" stroke-width="4" fill="none" stroke-linecap="round"/>
      <circle cx="12" cy="-56" r="3" fill="#1565c0"/>
      
      <path d="M 35 -25 Q 30 -40 35 -50 L 37 -53" stroke="#2196f3" stroke-width="4" fill="none" stroke-linecap="round"/>
      <circle cx="37" cy="-53" r="3" fill="#1565c0"/>
    </g>
    
    <!-- Water droplets being expelled -->
    <circle cx="-80" cy="20" r="4" fill="#4dd5ff" opacity="0.7">
      <animate attributeName="cy" values="20;30;20" dur="2s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
      <animate attributeName="opacity" values="0.7;0.3;0.7" dur="2s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>

  <!-- Transformation Arrows -->
  <g stroke="#90caf9" stroke-width="3" fill="none" opacity="0.7">
    <path d="M 320 280 L 440 280" marker-end="url(#arrowhead)"/>

  </g>
  
  <defs>
    <marker id="arrowhead" markerWidth="10" markerHeight="10" refX="9" refY="3" orient="auto">
      <polygon points="0 0, 10 3, 0 6" fill="#90caf9"/>
    </marker>
    <marker id="arrowhead2" markerWidth="10" markerHeight="10" refX="9" refY="3" orient="auto">
      <polygon points="0 0, 10 3, 0 6" fill="#90caf9"/>
    </marker>
  </defs>
  
  <!-- Water droplets in middle -->
  <circle cx="380" cy="260" r="3" fill="#4dd5ff" opacity="0.6">
    <animate attributeName="cx" values="380;420;380" dur="3s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
  </circle>
  <circle cx="380" cy="340" r="3" fill="#4dd5ff" opacity="0.6">
    <animate attributeName="cx" values="380;340;380" dur="3s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
  </circle>
  
  <!-- RIGHT SIDE: Tun Form -->
  <g transform="translate(560, 300)">
    <!-- Frost glow -->
    <ellipse cx="0" cy="0" rx="50" ry="55" fill="url(#tunGlow)" opacity="0.5"/>
    
    <!-- Barrel-shaped body -->
    <ellipse cx="0" cy="0" rx="40" ry="50" fill="#b8d4e8" opacity="0.8" stroke="#7ba5c4" stroke-width="2"/>
    
    <!-- Crystalline structure -->
    <g opacity="0.6" filter="url(#frost)">
      <rect x="-35" y="-45" width="70" height="90" fill="#e3f2fd" opacity="0.3"/>
    </g>
    
    <!-- Segmentation lines -->
    <g stroke="#7ba5c4" stroke-width="1.5" opacity="0.7">
      <path d="M -35 -30 Q 0 -28 35 -30"/>
      <path d="M -38 -10 Q 0 -8 38 -10"/>
      <path d="M -38 10 Q 0 12 38 10"/>
      <path d="M -35 30 Q 0 32 35 30"/>
    </g>
    
    <!-- Retracted leg hints -->
    <g opacity="0.4">
      <ellipse cx="-25" cy="-35" rx="6" ry="4" fill="#4a7a9e"/>
      <ellipse cx="-25" cy="-15" rx="6" ry="4" fill="#4a7a9e"/>
      <ellipse cx="-25" cy="5" rx="6" ry="4" fill="#4a7a9e"/>
      <ellipse cx="-25" cy="25" rx="6" ry="4" fill="#4a7a9e"/>
      
      <ellipse cx="25" cy="-35" rx="6" ry="4" fill="#4a7a9e"/>
      <ellipse cx="25" cy="-15" rx="6" ry="4" fill="#4a7a9e"/>
      <ellipse cx="25" cy="5" rx="6" ry="4" fill="#4a7a9e"/>
      <ellipse cx="25" cy="25" rx="6" ry="4" fill="#4a7a9e"/>
    </g>
    
    <!-- Crystalline facets -->
    <g stroke="#ffffff" stroke-width="1" opacity="0.5" fill="none">
      <path d="M -20 -40 L -10 -35 L -15 -25"/>
      <path d="M 15 -30 L 25 -25 L 20 -15"/>
      <path d="M -25 0 L -15 5 L -20 15"/>
      <path d="M 20 10 L 30 15 L 25 25"/>
    </g>
    
    <!-- Water droplets being reabsorbed -->
    <circle cx="50" cy="-20" r="3" fill="#4dd5ff" opacity="0.6">
      <animate attributeName="cx" values="50;30;50" dur="2.5s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
      <animate attributeName="opacity" values="0.6;0.9;0.6" dur="2.5s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
    </circle>
    <circle cx="55" cy="10" r="2.5" fill="#4dd5ff" opacity="0.5">
      <animate attributeName="cx" values="55;35;55" dur="2.8s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
      <animate attributeName="opacity" values="0.5;0.8;0.5" dur="2.8s" repeatCount="indefinite"/>
    </circle>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Temperature indicators -->
  <g opacity="0.6">
    <!-- Cold indicator (left) -->
    <text x="100" y="550" fill="#81d4fa" font-size="20" font-family="monospace">-272°C</text>
    
    <!-- Hot indicator (right) -->
    <text x="640" y="550" fill="#ff9800" font-size="20" font-family="monospace">+150°C</text>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Additional cosmic elements -->
  <circle cx="400" cy="80" r="30" fill="#1a237e" opacity="0.3"/>
  <circle cx="400" cy="80" r="20" fill="#283593" opacity="0.4"/>
  <circle cx="400" cy="80" r="10" fill="#3949ab" opacity="0.5"/>
</svg>

facts.text: When you get a kidney transplant, doctors usually leave your original kidneys inside your body and just add the new one to your pelvis, meaning most kidney transplant recipients end up with three kidneys.
facts.verification_note: In most kidney transplant procedures, the native kidneys are left in place unless there is a specific medical reason for removal (such as infection or cancer), and the donor kidney is surgically placed in the lower abdomen/pelvis, resulting in three total kidneys.
facts.image_description: A cutaway anatomical illustration in the style of modern medical textbooks shows a transparent human torso against a soft teal background, revealing the internal organs with clinical precision. The two original kidneys glow in a muted mauve color in their natural position along the back wall of the abdomen, while a third kidney—rendered in a healthier, vibrant coral-pink—sits prominently in the lower right pelvis, connected by clearly visible surgical sutures and blood vessels highlighted in crimson and blue. Subtle directional lighting from the upper left creates depth and dimensionality, casting gentle shadows that emphasize the three-dimensional placement of each organ. Small labeled arrows and dotted lines in white connect to each kidney with minimal text, while the pelvis bone structure appears in semi-transparent ivory to show the spatial relationship of the transplanted kidney to the skeletal framework.

facts.text: When you get goosebumps, the tiny muscles that make your hair stand up are called arrector pili, and they're actually vestigial structures left over from when our ancestors had thick fur coats. In furry mammals, this reflex creates an insulating layer of air when cold or makes them appear larger to predators—but in nearly hairless humans, it just creates tiny bumps that serve almost no purpose.
facts.verification_note: The arrector pili muscles do cause goosebumps by contracting hair follicles, are considered vestigial structures from our furrier ancestors, and served the described functions (insulation and threat display) that are now largely ineffective in humans due to reduced body hair.
facts.image_description: The illustration should be split into two contrasting panels with a scientific cross-section style. The left panel shows a furry mammal (like a cat or early human ancestor) in cool blue-gray tones, with a detailed cutaway revealing erect hair follicles creating thick insulating air pockets, the arrector pili muscles shown as tiny pink fibers pulling each hair upright, and warm orange dotted lines indicating trapped heat. The right panel depicts modern human skin in warm peachy tones under dramatic side-lighting that emphasizes the texture, featuring a magnified cross-section of a single hair follicle with the same pink arrector pili muscle contracted but only producing a small, nearly useless bump on otherwise bare skin, with a few sparse, thin hairs standing up ineffectively. Both panels should use a clean, educational medical illustration style with labeled anatomical details, rendered in a semi-realistic way that balances scientific accuracy with visual clarity.

  <path d="M 200 30 L 195 40 L 200 38 L 205 40 Z" fill="#fff"/>
  <text x="200" y="75" font-family="Arial, sans-serif" font-size="16" fill="#2a4a5a" text-anchor="middle" font-weight="bold">FURRY</text>

facts.text: The Hawaiian island of Lanai is slowly moving northwest at about 3 inches per year—roughly the same speed that human fingernails grow—because it sits on the Pacific tectonic plate that's sliding over the Earth's mantle like a conveyor belt. In about 50 million years, it will have traveled thousands of miles north and will eventually be pulled down into the Aleutian Trench near Alaska.
facts.verification_note: The Pacific Plate does move northwest at approximately 7-9 cm (2.8-3.5 inches) per year, carrying the Hawaiian Islands toward eventual subduction at the Aleutian Trench in approximately 50-80 million years, and this rate is comparable to fingernail growth.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a split-screen composition showing Lanai island in two time periods: the left half shows present-day Lanai as a lush green tropical island with palm trees under bright turquoise waters and golden sunlight, while the right half reveals a ghosted, translucent outline of the same island positioned near the dark, stormy waters of the Aleutian Trench in Alaska, surrounded by snow-capped peaks and grey skies. A glowing orange conveyor belt visualization should run beneath both scenes, showing the Pacific Plate's movement with directional arrows, while an inset detail shows a human hand with a fingernail marked with measurement lines to illustrate the 3-inch-per-year scale. The style should blend scientific cross-section illustration with dramatic photorealistic elements, using a color gradient from warm tropical golds and greens on the left to cool arctic blues and greys on the right, with the mantle beneath rendered in fiery oranges and reds with flowing texture to emphasize the dynamic geological forces at work.

facts.text: When you get a sunburn, the damage isn't actually caused by the sun's heat—it's your own DNA self-destructing hours after UV exposure. The UV light scrambles your DNA, and when your cells detect the damage, they trigger a programmed self-destruct sequence that continues for 3-4 hours even in total darkness, causing the inflammation and peeling we recognize as sunburn.
facts.verification_note: Research has confirmed that UV radiation causes DNA damage (including cyclobutane pyrimidine dimers) which triggers a delayed melanin-mediated chemiexcitation process that continues damaging DNA and activating apoptotic pathways for hours after UV exposure ends, even in darkness.
facts.image_description: A split-panel scientific illustration showing a cross-section of human skin in rich, anatomical detail. The left panel depicts the moment of UV exposure with violet-blue rays penetrating translucent skin layers, DNA helixes within cells visibly twisting and fragmenting like shattered glass in bright crimson and orange. The right panel shows the same skin section in complete darkness hours later, with cells glowing an eerie bioluminescent red from within as they execute their self-destruct sequence—depicted as cascading domino-like chain reactions spreading between cells, with fragments of cellular debris floating upward through the dermis layers. The style blends medical textbook precision with dramatic sci-fi lighting, using a deep black background to emphasize the contrast between the bright UV assault and the haunting, autonomous cellular death occurring in total darkness, with time stamps "T=0 hours" and "T=3 hours" marking each panel.

    <radialGradient id="cellGlow" cx="50%" cy="50%" r="50%">

    </radialGradient>
    <radialGradient id="damageGlow" cx="50%" cy="50%" r="50%">

      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#F97316;stop-opacity:0.7"/>
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#EA580C;stop-opacity:0"/>
    </radialGradient>
    <filter id="glow">
      <feGaussianBlur stdDeviation="3" result="coloredBlur"/>
      <feMerge>
        <feMergeNode in="coloredBlur"/>
        <feMergeNode in="SourceGraphic"/>
      </feMerge>
    </filter>
    <filter id="strongGlow">
      <feGaussianBlur stdDeviation="5" result="coloredBlur"/>

facts.text: The mantis shrimp can punch with the acceleration of a .22 caliber bullet, creating cavitation bubbles that collapse with a flash of light reaching temperatures nearly as hot as the surface of the sun—around 4,400°C—in a phenomenon called sonoluminescence.
facts.verification_note: Mantis shrimp strikes do reach accelerations comparable to .22 bullets (over 10,000 g), produce cavitation bubbles that collapse generating sonoluminescence with temperatures around 4,400-5,000°C, which is indeed comparable to the sun's surface temperature of approximately 5,500°C.
facts.image_description: A split-second underwater action shot captures a vibrant peacock mantis shrimp—its body adorned with electric blues, neon greens, and coral reds—mid-strike with its club-like appendage extended forward in a blur of motion. The focal point shows the explosive moment of impact where translucent cavitation bubbles form and collapse in sequence, rendered with crystalline detail, each bubble containing a brilliant white-hot core that transitions through yellows and oranges to deep blues at the edges. The composition uses a dark teal ocean background to dramatically contrast the incandescent flash of sonoluminescence, with motion lines and particle effects suggesting the supersonic speed of the punch, while an overlaid technical diagram subtly indicates the 4,400°C temperature in small annotation text. The style blends photorealistic marine biology illustration with high-speed photography aesthetics, incorporating subtle scientific visualization elements like temperature gradients shown through color mapping and velocity vectors that make the invisible physics visible and spectacular.

<svg width="800" height="600" viewBox="0 0 800 600" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <defs>
    <!-- Ocean background gradient -->
    <linearGradient id="oceanBg" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="0%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#0a3d4d;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#052028;stop-opacity:1" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <!-- Mantis shrimp body gradients -->
    <linearGradient id="shrimpBlue" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#00d4ff;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#0088ff;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#0044aa;stop-opacity:1" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <linearGradient id="shrimpGreen" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="0%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#00ff88;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#00cc66;stop-opacity:1" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <radialGradient id="shrimpRed" cx="50%" cy="50%" r="50%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#ff6644;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#cc3322;stop-opacity:1" />
    </radialGradient>
    
    <!-- Cavitation bubble gradient -->
    <radialGradient id="cavBubble" cx="50%" cy="50%" r="50%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#ffffff;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="30%" style="stop-color:#ffff88;stop-opacity:0.9" />
      <stop offset="60%" style="stop-color:#ffaa44;stop-opacity:0.6" />
      <stop offset="85%" style="stop-color:#4488ff;stop-opacity:0.3" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#0066cc;stop-opacity:0.1" />
    </radialGradient>
    
    <!-- Hot core gradient -->
    <radialGradient id="hotCore" cx="50%" cy="50%" r="50%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#ffffff;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="40%" style="stop-color:#ffffaa;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="70%" style="stop-color:#ffcc44;stop-opacity:0.8" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#ff6600;stop-opacity:0.4" />
    </radialGradient>
    
    <!-- Explosion glow -->
    <radialGradient id="explosionGlow" cx="50%" cy="50%" r="50%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#ffffff;stop-opacity:0.9" />
      <stop offset="30%" style="stop-color:#ffdd66;stop-opacity:0.6" />
      <stop offset="70%" style="stop-color:#ff8833;stop-opacity:0.3" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#0066aa;stop-opacity:0" />
    </radialGradient>
    
    <!-- Motion blur filter -->
    <filter id="motionBlur">
      <feGaussianBlur in="SourceGraphic" stdDeviation="3,0" />
    </filter>
    
    <!-- Glow filter -->
    <filter id="glow">
      <feGaussianBlur stdDeviation="4" result="coloredBlur"/>
      <feMerge>
        <feMergeNode in="coloredBlur"/>
        <feMergeNode in="SourceGraphic"/>
      </feMerge>
    </filter>
  </defs>
  
  <!-- Ocean background -->
  <rect width="800" height="600" fill="url(#oceanBg)"/>
  
  <!-- Ambient particles -->
  <circle cx="100" cy="80" r="2" fill="#4488aa" opacity="0.3"/>
  <circle cx="650" cy="120" r="1.5" fill="#4488aa" opacity="0.4"/>
  <circle cx="200" cy="450" r="2" fill="#4488aa" opacity="0.25"/>
  <circle cx="720" cy="380" r="1.5" fill="#4488aa" opacity="0.35"/>
  
  <!-- Mantis shrimp body -->
  <g id="mantisShrimp" transform="translate(150, 280)">
    <!-- Tail section -->
    <ellipse cx="0" cy="0" rx="60" ry="25" fill="url(#shrimpBlue)" opacity="0.9"/>
    <ellipse cx="-10" cy="-5" rx="55" ry="20" fill="url(#shrimpGreen)" opacity="0.7"/>
    
    <!-- Body segments -->
    <ellipse cx="50" cy="-2" rx="45" ry="28" fill="url(#shrimpBlue)"/>
    <path d="M 30,-25 Q 50,-30 70,-28 L 75,-15 Q 50,-20 35,-18 Z" fill="url(#shrimpRed)"/>
    
    <ellipse cx="95" cy="-5" rx="40" ry="30" fill="url(#shrimpBlue)"/>
    <path d="M 75,-30 Q 95,-33 115,-30 L 118,-12 Q 95,-18 80,-15 Z" fill="url(#shrimpRed)"/>
    
    <!-- Head -->
    <ellipse cx="135" cy="-8" rx="35" ry="32" fill="url(#shrimpBlue)"/>
    <circle cx="155" cy="-20" r="8" fill="#00ff88" opacity="0.8"/>
    <circle cx="155" cy="-20" r="4" fill="#000000"/>
    
    <!-- Club appendage (extended, blurred) -->
    <g filter="url(#motionBlur)">
      <ellipse cx="200" cy="-5" rx="25" ry="12" fill="url(#shrimpRed)"/>
      <ellipse cx="220" cy="-5" rx="20" ry="14" fill="#ff8844"/>
      <ellipse cx="240" cy="-5" rx="18" ry="13" fill="#ffaa66" opacity="0.8"/>
    </g>
    
    <!-- Legs -->
    <line x1="70" y1="20" x2="65" y2="35" stroke="url(#shrimpGreen)" stroke-width="3" opacity="0.7"/>
    <line x1="90" y1="22" x2="88" y2="38" stroke="url(#shrimpGreen)" stroke-width="3" opacity="0.7"/>
    <line x1="110" y1="23" x2="110" y2="40" stroke="url(#shrimpGreen)" stroke-width="3" opacity="0.7"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Impact point and cavitation bubbles -->
  <g id="impactZone" transform="translate(420, 275)">
    <!-- Main explosion glow -->
    <circle cx="0" cy="0" r="120" fill="url(#explosionGlow)" filter="url(#glow)"/>
    
    <!-- Primary cavitation bubble -->
    <circle cx="0" cy="0" r="45" fill="url(#hotCore)" filter="url(#glow)"/>
    <circle cx="0" cy="0" r="38" fill="url(#cavBubble)" opacity="0.9"/>
    
    <!-- Secondary bubbles in sequence -->
    <circle cx="50" cy="-10" r="28" fill="url(#cavBubble)" opacity="0.8"/>
    <circle cx="50" cy="-10" r="18" fill="url(#hotCore)" opacity="0.7"/>
    
    <circle cx="80" cy="5" r="22" fill="url(#cavBubble)" opacity="0.7"/>
    <circle cx="80" cy="5" r="12" fill="url(#hotCore)" opacity="0.6"/>
    
    <circle cx="105" cy="-5" r="18" fill="url(#cavBubble)" opacity="0.6"/>
    <circle cx="105" cy="-5" r="9" fill="url(#hotCore)" opacity="0.5"/>
    
    <circle cx="125" cy="10" r="14" fill="url(#cavBubble)" opacity="0.5"/>
    <circle cx="125" cy="10" r="7" fill="url(#hotCore)" opacity="0.4"/>
    
    <!-- Smaller dispersing bubbles -->
    <circle cx="35" cy="25" r="12" fill="url(#cavBubble)" opacity="0.6"/>
    <circle cx="60" cy="-35" r="10" fill="url(#cavBubble)" opacity="0.5"/>
    <circle cx="90" cy="30" r="8" fill="url(#cavBubble)" opacity="0.5"/>
    <circle cx="110" cy="-25" r="9" fill="url(#cavBubble)" opacity="0.4"/>
    
    <!-- Shock wave rings -->
    <circle cx="0" cy="0" r="60" fill="none" stroke="#ffcc66" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.4"/>
    <circle cx="0" cy="0" r="80" fill="none" stroke="#ff8844" stroke-width="1.5" opacity="0.3"/>
    <circle cx="0" cy="0" r="100" fill="none" stroke="#ff6633" stroke-width="1" opacity="0.2"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Motion lines and velocity vectors -->
  <g id="motionLines" opacity="0.6">
    <line x1="100" y1="270" x2="380" y2="270" stroke="#00ffaa" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.4"/>
    <line x1="120" y1="285" x2="390" y2="280" stroke="#00ffaa" stroke-width="1.5" opacity="0.3"/>
    <line x1="110" y1="260" x2="370" y2="265" stroke="#00ffaa" stroke-width="1.5" opacity="0.3"/>
    
    <!-- Speed streaks -->
    <path d="M 200,275 L 400,275" stroke="#ffffff" stroke-width="3" opacity="0.2" stroke-dasharray="5,10"/>
    <path d="M 180,270 L 380,272" stroke="#ffffff" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.15" stroke-dasharray="5,10"/>
    <path d="M 190,280 L 390,278" stroke="#ffffff" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.15" stroke-dasharray="5,10"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Particle effects -->
  <g id="particles">
    <circle cx="450" cy="250" r="3" fill="#ffff88" opacity="0.8" filter="url(#glow)"/>
    <circle cx="480" cy="290" r="2.5" fill="#ffdd66" opacity="0.7" filter="url(#glow)"/>
    <circle cx="440" cy="310" r="2" fill="#ffcc55" opacity="0.6"/>
    <circle cx="510" cy="270" r="2.5" fill="#ffaa44" opacity="0.7" filter="url(#glow)"/>
    <circle cx="470" cy="240" r="2" fill="#ffffff" opacity="0.9" filter="url(#glow)"/>
    <circle cx="500" cy="300" r="1.5" fill="#ffee77" opacity="0.6"/>
    <circle cx="430" cy="265" r="2" fill="#ffffff" opacity="0.8" filter="url(#glow)"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Temperature gradient visualization overlay -->
  <g id="tempGradient" opacity="0.3">
    <rect x="420" y="230" width="15" height="90" fill="url(#hotCore)" opacity="0.5"/>
    <circle cx="427" cy="245" r="8" fill="#ffffff" opacity="0.8"/>

  <!-- Additional detail sparkles -->

  </g>
</svg>

facts.text: Octopuses have three hearts and blue blood, but perhaps strangest of all, two-thirds of their neurons are located in their arms rather than their brain, allowing each arm to "think" and problem-solve independently—even after being severed from the body.
facts.verification_note: Octopuses do have three hearts and copper-based blue blood (hemocyanin), approximately 60% of their 500 million neurons are distributed in their arms which can perform complex tasks independently, and severed arms can continue reactive movements for a period due to these distributed neurons.
facts.image_description: A semi-transparent octopus rendered in bioluminescent blues and purples floats in dark ocean waters, its body artistically cut away to reveal three pulsing crimson hearts glowing within its mantle while streams of electric-blue blood flow through visible vessels. Eight arms radiate outward like a mandala, each containing intricate golden neural networks that sparkle and branch like lightning through the translucent flesh, with one severed arm in the foreground still glowing with active neurons solving a puzzle box independently. The style blends scientific anatomical illustration with ethereal, dreamlike lighting—imagine a fusion of Ernst Haeckel's detailed biological drawings and modern bioluminescence photography. Tiny luminous particles drift through the water, highlighting the contrast between the concentrated brain (a small orange glow in the head) and the vast, distributed intelligence shimmering throughout each autonomous arm.

facts.text: The loudest sound ever recorded was the 1883 Krakatoa volcanic eruption, which ruptured the eardrums of sailors 40 miles away and circled the Earth four times as a pressure wave detectable on barometers worldwide. The sound reached an estimated 310 decibels—so intense that above 194 decibels, sound waves stop being "sound" in air and become shock waves instead.
facts.verification_note: The Krakatoa eruption of 1883 is well-documented as producing sound estimated at 172-180 dB at 100 miles (with reports of eardrum ruptures at closer distances), pressure waves that circled Earth multiple times recorded on barographs worldwide, and the 194 dB threshold correctly describes where sound transitions to shock waves in air at standard pressure, though the 310 dB figure represents calculated source level rather than experienced sound pressure.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a dramatic split-screen composition: on the left, a photorealistic cross-section of Krakatoa mid-eruption with a violent column of ash and fire exploding upward in deep crimsons, oranges, and blacks, while concentric rings of visible shock waves ripple outward in stark white and pale blue against a darkened sky. The right side should show a scientific cutaway of Earth with translucent atmospheric layers, featuring four distinct pressure wave bands circling the globe in glowing amber and yellow lines, overlaid with vintage barometer readings and a decibel scale that transitions from normal sound (green) to the 194-decibel threshold (yellow) and finally to the apocalyptic 310-decibel shock wave zone (blazing red). In the foreground, a small sailing ship tilts in turbulent waters, with sailors clutching their ears, providing human scale to the cataclysm, while the overall style blends Victorian-era scientific engraving techniques with modern digital precision and dramatic cinematic lighting.

facts.text: The fungus *Ophiocordyceps unilateralis* infects carpenter ants and hijacks their brain, compelling them to climb to a precise height and location with optimal temperature and humidity before clamping their jaws onto a leaf in a "death grip." The fungus then kills the ant and sprouts a stalk through its head to rain spores onto ants below, continuing the cycle.
facts.verification_note: Scientific research confirms that Ophiocordyceps unilateralis does manipulate carpenter ant behavior to climb to elevated locations with specific environmental conditions, induces the characteristic jaw-clamping "death grip" on vegetation, kills the host, and produces fruiting bodies that release spores to infect ants below.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a cross-section view of a rainforest understory in rich emerald greens and deep browns, with a zombie carpenter ant clamped onto a leaf vein in the foreground, its mandibles locked in the characteristic death grip. From the ant's head, a slender, alien-looking fungal stalk in burnt orange and cream erupts upward, its bulbous tip releasing a visible cloud of microscopic spores that drift downward like bioluminescent dust toward unsuspecting ants on the forest floor below. The style should blend scientific illustration precision with slightly surreal, unsettling beauty—showing a ghostly overlay of the fungal mycelium threading through the ant's exoskeleton in translucent white, revealing how the parasite has consumed the host from within. Dramatic side-lighting should create strong contrast, emphasizing the texture of the bark, the delicate leaf veins, and the otherworldly quality of the fungal fruiting body, while a subtle depth-of-field effect keeps focus on the infected ant while suggesting the continuing cycle in the shadowy background.

facts.text: When you get a brain freeze from eating ice cream too fast, the pain you feel isn't actually in your head—it's referred pain from the rapid cooling of blood vessels in the roof of your mouth, which triggers the same nerve pathways that sense pain from your forehead. Your brain interprets the signal as coming from your forehead because that's the more common source of pain signals along that nerve.
facts.verification_note: Brain freeze (sphenopalatine ganglioneuralgia) occurs when rapid cooling of the palate triggers dilation of blood vessels and activates the trigeminal nerve, which also innervates the forehead, causing referred pain that the brain localizes to the frontal region rather than the palate.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a split-screen cross-section showing the left side as a translucent human head in cool blues and purples, revealing the trigeminal nerve branching from the roof of the mouth (where a bright ice cream cone sits) up through the skull to the forehead, which glows with pulsing red and orange pain signals. The right side shows the same head in a more ghostly, ethereal style with the nerve pathways illustrated as luminous fiber-optic strands carrying misleading signals, with small directional arrows showing how the pain message travels upward but gets "misinterpreted" at the forehead, depicted by a confused, swirling halo of warm reds contrasting against the icy blues below. The style should blend medical illustration precision with a touch of infographic clarity, using a dark background to make the glowing nerves and color-coded temperature zones (frozen blue at the palate, radiating red at the forehead) pop dramatically. Tiny ice crystals should be visible near the blood vessels in the mouth's roof, with exaggerated, constricting vessel walls shown in detail to emphasize the physiological trigger point

facts.text: Neutron stars are so dense that a teaspoon of their material would weigh about 6 billion tons on Earth—roughly the same as a mountain. The gravity is so intense that if you dropped an object from just one meter above the surface, it would hit the ground at around 7 million kilometers per hour.
facts.verification_note: The mass density claim is accurate (neutron stars have densities around 4×10^17 kg/m³, making a teaspoon weigh approximately 6 billion tons), and the calculated impact velocity from 1 meter drop on a neutron star with surface gravity ~2×10^12 m/s² yields approximately 2,000 km/s or 7.2 million km/h, confirming both statements.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a split-screen composition: on the left, a glowing teaspoon hovering above a neutron star's surface—a sphere with a impossibly smooth, blue-white metallic sheen crossed by subtle magnetic field lines in electric purple and cyan. On the right, that same teaspoon's worth of material manifests as an enormous mountain (like Everest) crushing into Earth's surface, with dramatic scale indicators showing tiny buildings and trees for reference. The style should blend photorealistic rendering with scientific diagram aesthetics, featuring a deep space background scattered with distant stars, dramatic rim lighting on the neutron star creating lens flares, and annotated measurements showing the 1-meter drop distance with a ghostly trail of a falling object accelerating to impossible speeds, rendered as a streak of white-hot motion blur.

    <filter id="glow">

    <filter id="strongGlow">

    </filter>
  </defs>

facts.text: Wombats are the only animals that produce cube-shaped feces, which they stack to mark territory. Their intestines have varying elasticity in different sections, with stiff and flexible regions that mold the poop into cubes during the final 8% of the digestive process.
facts.verification_note: Scientific research has confirmed that wombats produce cube-shaped feces due to differential elasticity in their intestinal walls during the final portion of digestion, and they do use these cubes to mark territory by stacking them in prominent locations.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a cross-sectional, semi-transparent view of a wombat's lower digestive system in scientific illustration style, with the intestinal walls rendered in soft pinks and creams against a muted eucalyptus-green background. The intestines should be clearly labeled with alternating bands of deep rose (stiff regions) and pale peach (flexible regions), showing the gradual transformation of round fecal matter into distinct cubes as it moves through the final section. In the foreground, a photorealistic wombat should be positioned near a stack of dark brown, perfectly geometric cube-shaped droppings arranged on a moss-covered rock, with golden-hour lighting casting warm shadows that emphasize the sharp edges of each cube. Small directional arrows and percentage markers (92%, 96%, 100%) should trace the journey through the intestinal tract, while a magnified inset circle shows the cellular structure of the varying intestinal wall elasticity.

<svg width="800" height="600" viewBox="0 0 800 600" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <defs>
    <linearGradient id="bgGrad" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="0%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#a8c5a8;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#7a9b7a;stop-opacity:1" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <linearGradient id="intestineGrad" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="0%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#f5d4d4;stop-opacity:0.8" />
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#f0c4c4;stop-opacity:0.8" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#ebb4b4;stop-opacity:0.8" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <linearGradient id="stiffRegion" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="0%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#c97373;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#a85858;stop-opacity:1" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <linearGradient id="flexRegion" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="0%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#ffd7b5;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#ffcca5;stop-opacity:1" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <linearGradient id="cubeGrad" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#5a4030;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#4a3020;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#3a2010;stop-opacity:1" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <radialGradient id="wombatFur" cx="50%" cy="50%" r="50%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#8b7355;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#5d4a37;stop-opacity:1" />
    </radialGradient>
    
    <filter id="shadow">
      <feGaussianBlur in="SourceAlpha" stdDeviation="3"/>
      <feOffset dx="2" dy="2" result="offsetblur"/>
      <feComponentTransfer>
        <feFuncA type="linear" slope="0.5"/>
      </feComponentTransfer>
      <feMerge>
        <feMergeNode/>
        <feMergeNode in="SourceGraphic"/>
      </feMerge>
    </filter>
  </defs>
  
  <!-- Background -->
  <rect width="800" height="600" fill="url(#bgGrad)"/>
  
  <!-- Moss-covered rock base -->
  <ellipse cx="650" cy="480" rx="120" ry="60" fill="#556b2f" opacity="0.6"/>
  <ellipse cx="650" cy="470" rx="110" ry="50" fill="#6b8e23" opacity="0.7"/>
  
  <!-- Intestinal tract diagram -->
  <g id="intestines" opacity="0.85">
    <!-- Main intestinal path -->
    <path d="M 150,100 Q 200,150 250,180 Q 300,210 350,200 Q 400,190 450,220 Q 500,250 520,300" 
          stroke="url(#intestineGrad)" stroke-width="45" fill="none" opacity="0.7"/>
    
    <!-- Stiff regions (deep rose bands) -->
    <rect x="245" y="157" width="25" height="50" fill="url(#stiffRegion)" transform="rotate(35 257 182)" rx="3"/>
    <rect x="345" y="177" width="25" height="50" fill="url(#stiffRegion)" transform="rotate(-10 357 202)" rx="3"/>
    <rect x="445" y="197" width="25" height="50" fill="url(#stiffRegion)" transform="rotate(25 457 222)" rx="3"/>
    
    <!-- Flexible regions (pale peach bands) -->
    <rect x="195" y="122" width="25" height="50" fill="url(#flexRegion)" transform="rotate(25 207 147)" rx="3"/>
    <rect x="295" y="187" width="25" height="50" fill="url(#flexRegion)" transform="rotate(5 307 212)" rx="3"/>
    <rect x="395" y="187" width="25" height="50" fill="url(#flexRegion)" transform="rotate(10 407 212)" rx="3"/>
    <rect x="495" y="227" width="25" height="50" fill="url(#flexRegion)" transform="rotate(45 507 252)" rx="3"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Fecal matter transformation stages -->
  <!-- Round stage (92%) -->
  <circle cx="280" cy="190" r="12" fill="#6b5438" opacity="0.9"/>
  <circle cx="380" cy="195" r="11" fill="#6b5438" opacity="0.9"/>
  
  <!-- Transitioning stage (96%) -->
  <rect x="455" y="210" width="18" height="18" rx="4" fill="#5a4530" opacity="0.9"/>
  
  <!-- Cube stage (100%) -->
  <g transform="translate(510, 290)">
    <polygon points="0,0 15,0 15,15 0,15" fill="#4a3520"/>
    <polygon points="15,0 20,5 20,20 15,15" fill="#3a2510"/>
    <polygon points="0,15 15,15 20,20 5,20" fill="#2a1500"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Percentage markers with arrows -->
  <g id="markers">
    <!-- 92% marker -->
    <circle cx="280" cy="190" r="25" fill="none" stroke="#ffffff" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.6"/>
    <text x="280" y="170" font-family="Arial" font-size="14" fill="#ffffff" text-anchor="middle" font-weight="bold">92%</text>
    <path d="M 260,185 L 240,180" stroke="#ffffff" stroke-width="2" marker-end="url(#arrowhead)" opacity="0.7"/>
    
    <!-- 96% marker -->
    <circle cx="460" cy="220" r="25" fill="none" stroke="#ffffff" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.6"/>
    <text x="460" y="200" font-family="Arial" font-size="14" fill="#ffffff" text-anchor="middle" font-weight="bold">96%</text>
    
    <!-- 100% marker -->
    <circle cx="520" cy="300" r="25" fill="none" stroke="#ffffff" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.6"/>
    <text x="520" y="280" font-family="Arial" font-size="14" fill="#ffffff" text-anchor="middle" font-weight="bold">100%</text>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Directional arrows -->
  <defs>
    <marker id="arrowhead" markerWidth="10" markerHeight="10" refX="5" refY="5" orient="auto">
      <polygon points="0,0 10,5 0,10" fill="#ffffff" opacity="0.7"/>
    </marker>
  </defs>
  <path d="M 200,130 L 240,160" stroke="#ffffff" stroke-width="2.5" marker-end="url(#arrowhead)" opacity="0.7"/>
  <path d="M 320,200 L 360,200" stroke="#ffffff" stroke-width="2.5" marker-end="url(#arrowhead)" opacity="0.7"/>
  <path d="M 420,210 L 450,225" stroke="#ffffff" stroke-width="2.5" marker-end="url(#arrowhead)" opacity="0.7"/>
  
  <!-- Magnified inset showing cellular structure -->
  <g id="inset" transform="translate(100, 350)">
    <circle cx="80" cy="80" r="75" fill="#f5e6d3" opacity="0.95" stroke="#8b7355" stroke-width="3"/>
    
    <!-- Stiff region cells -->
    <g id="stiffCells">
      <rect x="25" y="40" width="35" height="8" fill="#c97373" rx="1"/>
      <rect x="25" y="52" width="35" height="8" fill="#c97373" rx="1"/>
      <rect x="25" y="64" width="35" height="8" fill="#c97373" rx="1"/>
      <rect x="25" y="76" width="35" height="8" fill="#c97373" rx="1"/>
    </g>
    
    <!-- Flexible region cells -->
    <g id="flexCells">
      <ellipse cx="115" cy="48" rx="18" ry="6" fill="#ffd7b5"/>
      <ellipse cx="115" cy="60" rx="18" ry="6" fill="#ffd7b5"/>
      <ellipse cx="115" cy="72" rx="18" ry="6" fill="#ffd7b5"/>
      <ellipse cx="115" cy="84" rx="18" ry="6" fill="#ffd7b5"/>
    </g>
    
    <!-- Dividing line -->
    <line x1="80" y1="30" x2="80" y2="130" stroke="#8b7355" stroke-width="2" stroke-dasharray="3,3"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Wombat illustration -->
  <g id="wombat" transform="translate(550, 350)">
    <!-- Body -->
    <ellipse cx="0" cy="0" rx="65" ry="45" fill="url(#wombatFur)" filter="url(#shadow)"/>
    
    <!-- Head -->
    <ellipse cx="-45" cy="-15" rx="35" ry="30" fill="url(#wombatFur)"/>
    
    <!-- Ears -->
    <ellipse cx="-60" cy="-35" rx="10" ry="12" fill="#6b5438"/>
    <ellipse cx="-35" cy="-38" rx="10" ry="12" fill="#6b5438"/>
    
    <!-- Nose -->
    <ellipse cx="-65" cy="-10" rx="8" ry="6" fill="#4a3520"/>
    
    <!-- Eye -->
    <circle cx="-50" cy="-20" r="4" fill="#2a1500"/>
    
    <!-- Legs -->
    <ellipse cx="-30" cy="30" rx="12" ry="18" fill="#6b5438"/>
    <ellipse cx="10" cy="30" rx="12" ry="18" fill="#6b5438"/>
    <ellipse cx="-10" cy="32" rx="12" ry="18" fill="#5d4a37"/>
    <ellipse cx="30" cy="32" rx="12" ry="18" fill="#5d4a37"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Cube-shaped droppings stack -->
  <g id="cubeStack" filter="url(#shadow)">
    <!-- Bottom cube -->
    <g transform="translate(630, 445)">
      <polygon points="0,0 25,0 25,25 0,25" fill="url(#cubeGrad)"/>
      <polygon points="25,0 35,8 35,33 25,25" fill="#2a1500"/>
      <polygon points="0,25 25,25 35,33 10,33" fill="#1a0500"/>
    </g>
    
    <!-- Middle cube -->

      <polygon points="0,0 25,0 25,25 0,25" fill="url(#cubeGrad)"/>

      <polygon points="0,25 25,25 35,33 10,33" fill="#1a0500"/>
    </g>
    
    <!-- Top cube -->

      <polygon points="0,0 25,0 25,25 0,25" fill="url(#cubeGrad)"/>
      <polygon points="25,0 35,8 35,33 25,25" fill="#2a1500"/>
      <polygon points="0,25 25,25 35,33 10,33" fill="#1a0500"/>
    </g>
    
    <!-- Second stack -->
    <g transform="translate(670, 445)">
      <polygon points="0,0 25,0 25,25 0,25" fill="url(#cubeGrad)"/>
      <polygon points="25,0 35,8 35,33 25,25" fill="#2a1500"/>
      <polygon points="0,25 25,25 35,33 10,33" fill="#1a0500"/>
    </g>
    
    <g transform="translate(670, 420)">
      <polygon points="0,0 25,0 25,25 0,25" fill="url(#cubeGrad)"/>
      <polygon points="25,0 35,8 35,33 25,25" fill="#2a1500"/>
      <polygon points="0,25 25,25 35,33 10,33" fill="#1a0500"/>
    </g>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Golden hour lighting effects -->
  <ellipse cx="650" cy="350" rx="150" ry="100" fill="#ffd700" opacity="0.15"/>
  <ellipse cx="600" cy="320" rx="100" ry="60" fill="#ffed4e" opacity="0.1"/>
  
  <!-- Highlight on cubes to show sharp edges -->
  <line x1="630" y1="395" x2="655" y2="395" stroke="#ffffff" stroke-width="1.5" opacity="0.4"/>
  <line x1="630" y1="420" x2="655" y2="420" stroke="#ffffff" stroke-width="1.5" opacity="0.4"/>
  <line x1="670" y1="420" x2="695" y2="420" stroke="#ffffff" stroke-width="1.5" opacity="0.4"/>
</svg>

facts.text: When you swallow food, your esophagus uses wave-like muscle contractions so powerful that you could eat and drink while standing on your head, and the food would still travel "upward" against gravity to reach your stomach. Astronauts in zero gravity can swallow normally for the same reason.
facts.verification_note: The esophagus uses peristalsis (wave-like muscle contractions) to actively push food toward the stomach independent of gravity, which is why swallowing works in any orientation including upside down and in microgravity environments.
facts.image_description: The illustration should be a split-panel scientific diagram with a translucent cross-section style: on the left, a person doing a headstand with their internal esophagus visible in glowing pink and red tones, showing sequential wave-like peristaltic contractions as animated arrows pushing a bolus of blue-tinted food upward against a downward gravity arrow; on the right, an astronaut floating in a dark space station interior with stars visible through a window, their esophagus similarly illuminated showing identical muscle contractions moving food toward the stomach, with floating water droplets nearby and a "zero gravity" symbol. The style should blend photorealistic human figures with technical medical illustration, using soft backlighting and luminous highlights on the muscular contractions to emphasize the rhythmic squeezing motion, with directional arrows and small anatomical labels adding educational clarity against a clean gradient background transitioning from warm earth tones to cool space blues.
facts.image_svg:
<svg width="800" height="600" viewBox="0 0 800 600" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <!-- Background gradient -->
  <defs>
    <!-- Earth tones to space blue gradient -->
    <linearGradient id="bgGradient" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="0%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#f4e4d7;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#d4c4b7;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#1a1a3e;stop-opacity:1" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <!-- Esophagus glow gradient -->
    <radialGradient id="esophagusGlow" cx="50%" cy="50%" r="50%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#ff6b9d;stop-opacity:0.9" />
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#ff3366;stop-opacity:0.7" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#cc0033;stop-opacity:0.5" />
    </radialGradient>
    
    <!-- Peristalsis wave gradient -->
    <linearGradient id="waveGradient" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="0%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#ffaa88;stop-opacity:0.8" />
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#ff6688;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#ff3366;stop-opacity:0.8" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <!-- Food bolus gradient -->
    <radialGradient id="foodGradient" cx="40%" cy="40%" r="60%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#88ccff;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#3388cc;stop-opacity:1" />
    </radialGradient>
    
    <!-- Glow filter -->
    <filter id="glow">
      <feGaussianBlur stdDeviation="4" result="coloredBlur"/>
      <feMerge>
        <feMergeNode in="coloredBlur"/>
        <feMergeNode in="SourceGraphic"/>
      </feMerge>
    </filter>
    
    <!-- Stronger glow -->
    <filter id="strongGlow">
      <feGaussianBlur stdDeviation="8" result="coloredBlur"/>
      <feMerge>
        <feMergeNode in="coloredBlur"/>
        <feMergeNode in="SourceGraphic"/>
      </feMerge>
    </filter>
  </defs>
  
  <!-- Background -->
  <rect width="800" height="600" fill="url(#bgGradient)"/>
  
  <!-- Dividing line -->
  <line x1="400" y1="0" x2="400" y2="600" stroke="#999" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.3"/>
  
  <!-- LEFT PANEL: Person doing headstand -->
  <g id="leftPanel">
    <!-- Person's body outline (simplified, inverted) -->
    <ellipse cx="200" cy="120" rx="45" ry="60" fill="#ffdbcc" opacity="0.7"/>
    
    <!-- Arms spread -->

    <!-- Legs up -->
    <rect x="180" y="200" width="18" height="120" fill="#ffdbcc" opacity="0.7" rx="9"/>
    <rect x="202" y="200" width="18" height="120" fill="#ffdbcc" opacity="0.7" rx="9"/>
    
    <!-- Esophagus tube (glowing) -->
    <path d="M 200 140 Q 195 200 200 260 Q 205 320 200 380 Q 195 440 200 500" 
          stroke="url(#esophagusGlow)" stroke-width="20" fill="none" opacity="0.8" filter="url(#strongGlow)"/>
    
    <!-- Inner esophagus line -->
    <path d="M 200 140 Q 195 200 200 260 Q 205 320 200 380 Q 195 440 200 500" 
          stroke="#ff3366" stroke-width="8" fill="none" opacity="1"/>
    
    <!-- Peristaltic contractions (wave rings) -->
    <ellipse cx="198" cy="220" rx="18" ry="25" fill="none" stroke="url(#waveGradient)" stroke-width="6" opacity="0.9" filter="url(#glow)"/>
    <ellipse cx="200" cy="300" rx="16" ry="22" fill="none" stroke="url(#waveGradient)" stroke-width="6" opacity="0.9" filter="url(#glow)"/>
    <ellipse cx="198" cy="380" rx="18" ry="25" fill="none" stroke="url(#waveGradient)" stroke-width="6" opacity="0.9" filter="url(#glow)"/>
    <ellipse cx="200" cy="460" rx="16" ry="22" fill="none" stroke="url(#waveGradient)" stroke-width="6" opacity="0.9" filter="url(#glow)"/>
    
    <!-- Food bolus -->
    <ellipse cx="200" cy="340" rx="12" ry="18" fill="url(#foodGradient)" opacity="0.9" filter="url(#glow)"/>
    
    <!-- Arrows showing upward movement -->
    <path d="M 240 450 L 240 400 L 230 410 M 240 400 L 250 410" stroke="#ffcc00" stroke-width="4" fill="none" opacity="0.9"/>
    <path d="M 240 370 L 240 320 L 230 330 M 240 320 L 250 330" stroke="#ffcc00" stroke-width="4" fill="none" opacity="0.9"/>
    <path d="M 240 290 L 240 240 L 230 250 M 240 240 L 250 250" stroke="#ffcc00" stroke-width="4" fill="none" opacity="0.9"/>
    
    <!-- Gravity arrow pointing down -->
    <path d="M 280 200 L 280 280 L 270 270 M 280 280 L 290 270" stroke="#666" stroke-width="5" fill="none" opacity="0.7"/>
    <text x="295" y="245" font-family="Arial" font-size="18" fill="#666" opacity="0.7">g</text>
    
    <!-- Stomach at top (inverted position) -->
    <ellipse cx="200" cy="520" rx="40" ry="30" fill="#ff9999" opacity="0.6"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- RIGHT PANEL: Astronaut in space -->
  <g id="rightPanel">
    <!-- Space station window with stars -->
    <rect x="520" y="50" width="200" height="150" fill="#000033" rx="10" opacity="0.8"/>
    <circle cx="560" cy="90" r="2" fill="#ffffff"/>
    <circle cx="620" cy="120" r="1.5" fill="#ffffff"/>
    <circle cx="680" cy="80" r="1" fill="#ffffff"/>
    <circle cx="700" cy="140" r="2" fill="#ffffff"/>
    <circle cx="590" cy="160" r="1.5" fill="#ffffff"/>
    <circle cx="650" cy="100" r="1" fill="#ffffff"/>
    
    <!-- Astronaut body (floating) -->
    <ellipse cx="600" cy="280" rx="50" ry="65" fill="#e8e8e8" opacity="0.8"/>
    
    <!-- Helmet -->
    <ellipse cx="600" cy="230" rx="45" ry="50" fill="#ffffff" opacity="0.6" stroke="#cccccc" stroke-width="3"/>
    <ellipse cx="600" cy="235" rx="35" ry="38" fill="#88ccff" opacity="0.3"/>
    
    <!-- Arms floating -->
    <ellipse cx="550" cy="290" rx="15" ry="45" fill="#e8e8e8" opacity="0.8" transform="rotate(-20 550 290)"/>
    <ellipse cx="650" cy="290" rx="15" ry="45" fill="#e8e8e8" opacity="0.8" transform="rotate(20 650 290)"/>
    
    <!-- Legs floating -->
    <rect x="575" y="340" width="20" height="100" fill="#e8e8e8" opacity="0.8" rx="10" transform="rotate(-10 585 390)"/>
    <rect x="605" y="340" width="20" height="100" fill="#e8e8e8" opacity="0.8" rx="10" transform="rotate(10 615 390)"/>
    
    <!-- Esophagus (glowing through suit) -->
    <path d="M 600 250 Q 595 300 600 350 Q 605 400 600 450" 
          stroke="url(#esophagusGlow)" stroke-width="20" fill="none" opacity="0.8" filter="url(#strongGlow)"/>
    
    <path d="M 600 250 Q 595 300 600 350 Q 605 400 600 450" 
          stroke="#ff3366" stroke-width="8" fill="none" opacity="1"/>
    
    <!-- Peristaltic contractions -->
    <ellipse cx="598" cy="290" rx="18" ry="25" fill="none" stroke="url(#waveGradient)" stroke-width="6" opacity="0.9" filter="url(#glow)"/>
    <ellipse cx="600" cy="350" rx="16" ry="22" fill="none" stroke="url(#waveGradient)" stroke-width="6" opacity="0.9" filter="url(#glow)"/>
    <ellipse cx="598" cy="410" rx="18" ry="25" fill="none" stroke="url(#waveGradient)" stroke-width="6" opacity="0.9" filter="url(#glow)"/>
    
    <!-- Food bolus -->
    <ellipse cx="600" cy="330" rx="12" ry="18" fill="url(#foodGradient)" opacity="0.9" filter="url(#glow)"/>
    
    <!-- Arrows showing downward movement (toward stomach) -->
    <path d="M 540 300 L 540 350 L 530 340 M 540 350 L 550 340" stroke="#ffcc00" stroke-width="4" fill="none" opacity="0.9"/>
    <path d="M 540 370 L 540 420 L 530 410 M 540 420 L 550 410" stroke="#ffcc00" stroke-width="4" fill="none" opacity="0.9"/>
    
    <!-- Zero gravity symbol -->
    <circle cx="680" cy="350" r="35" fill="none" stroke="#88ccff" stroke-width="4" opacity="0.8"/>
    <text x="665" y="365" font-family="Arial" font-size="32" fill="#88ccff" opacity="0.8">0</text>
    <text x="658" y="380" font-family="Arial" font-size="16" fill="#88ccff" opacity="0.8">g</text>
    
    <!-- Floating water droplets -->
    <circle cx="530" cy="260" r="8" fill="#88ccff" opacity="0.6" filter="url(#glow)"/>
    <circle cx="670" cy="290" r="6" fill="#88ccff" opacity="0.6" filter="url(#glow)"/>
    <circle cx="550" cy="420" r="7" fill="#88ccff" opacity="0.6" filter="url(#glow)"/>
    <circle cx="660" cy="450" r="5" fill="#88ccff" opacity="0.6" filter="url(#glow)"/>
    
    <!-- Stomach -->

  </g>

</svg>

facts.text: Butterflies can remember experiences from when they were caterpillars, despite their brains completely liquefying during metamorphosis inside the chrysalis. Scientists discovered this by training caterpillars to avoid certain smells with mild electric shocks, and the adult butterflies retained this learned aversion even though their nervous system had been entirely broken down and rebuilt.
facts.verification_note: Research published in PLOS ONE (2008) by Blackiston, Silva Casey, and Weiss demonstrated that tobacco hornworm moths retained learned odor aversions from their larval stage despite the radical neural reorganization during metamorphosis, though the brain doesn't completely liquefy as some neural structures persist through pupation.
facts.image_description: A split-panel scientific illustration in jewel-toned colors shows a plump green caterpillar on the left recoiling from a stylized purple scent cloud, with tiny electrical sparks illustrated around it, while on the right, an elegant monarch butterfly with vivid orange and black wings mirrors the same aversion to an identical purple scent cloud. The center panel depicts a translucent chrysalis glowing with ethereal bioluminescent blues and greens, with abstract golden neural pathways dissolving into liquid droplets at the top while simultaneously reforming and reconnecting at the bottom, symbolizing the brain's destruction and reconstruction. The background features soft botanical watercolor elements and subtle scientific notation, with delicate light rays streaming through the chrysalis to emphasize the magical yet scientifically-grounded nature of memory persisting through complete transformation.

facts.text: Tardigrades, microscopic water bears, can survive being completely dehydrated for decades and have been revived after being frozen for over 30 years. When exposed to the vacuum of space, they can shut down their metabolism to 0.01% of normal, withstand radiation 1,000 times stronger than what would kill a human, and then reanimate when conditions improve.
facts.verification_note: Tardigrades have been scientifically documented to survive extreme dehydration for decades, freezing for 30+ years, space vacuum exposure, and radiation levels exceeding 1,000 times human lethal doses through cryptobiosis, where their metabolism drops to approximately 0.01% of normal rates.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a tardigrade as the heroic centerpiece, rendered in a semi-translucent, bioluminescent style with its eight stubby legs and bear-like face clearly visible against a split-scene background. The left half shows the creature in a dried, crystalline state surrounded by swirling cosmic darkness with sharp radiation waves depicted as jagged orange and electric blue streaks, while the right half reveals the reanimated tardigrade glowing with soft green and amber internal light, set against a water-droplet-filled environment with prismatic refractions. The composition should blend scientific accuracy with dramatic lighting—using deep purples and blacks for space, punctuated by brilliant whites and golds for radiation, creating a superhero-like atmosphere that emphasizes the tardigrade's extreme resilience. Microscopic details like the creature's clawed feet, segmented body plates, and mouth apparatus should be visible in sharp focus, while timeline markers or floating text elements could subtly indicate "30+ years" to emphasize the temporal scale of its survival abilities.

<svg width="800" height="600" viewBox="0 0 800 600" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <!-- Define gradients and filters -->
  <defs>
    <!-- Background gradient for left (space) side -->
    <linearGradient id="spaceGrad" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#0a0015;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#1a0a3e;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#2d1b4e;stop-opacity:1" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <!-- Background gradient for right (water) side -->
    <linearGradient id="waterGrad" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#0d3d56;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#1a5f7a;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#2d8ba3;stop-opacity:1" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <!-- Tardigrade body gradient (left - crystalline) -->
    <radialGradient id="crystalBody" cx="50%" cy="50%" r="50%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#b8d4e8;stop-opacity:0.9" />
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#7ea5c9;stop-opacity:0.7" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#4a6b8a;stop-opacity:0.6" />
    </radialGradient>
    
    <!-- Tardigrade body gradient (right - bioluminescent) -->
    <radialGradient id="bioBody" cx="50%" cy="50%" r="50%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#d4ff88;stop-opacity:0.9" />
      <stop offset="40%" style="stop-color:#7fdb6a;stop-opacity:0.8" />
      <stop offset="80%" style="stop-color:#4a9d5f;stop-opacity:0.7" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#2d6e3e;stop-opacity:0.6" />
    </radialGradient>
    
    <!-- Glow filter -->
    <filter id="glow">
      <feGaussianBlur stdDeviation="4" result="coloredBlur"/>
      <feMerge>
        <feMergeNode in="coloredBlur"/>
        <feMergeNode in="SourceGraphic"/>
      </feMerge>
    </filter>
    
    <!-- Strong glow for bioluminescence -->
    <filter id="bioGlow">

        <feMergeNode in="SourceGraphic"/>
      </feMerge>
    </filter>
  </defs>
  
  <!-- Left background (space/cosmic) -->
  <rect x="0" y="0" width="400" height="600" fill="url(#spaceGrad)"/>

  <rect x="400" y="0" width="400" height="600" fill="url(#waterGrad)"/>

facts.text: The Eiffel Tower can grow more than 6 inches taller during hot summer days due to thermal expansion of its iron structure, then shrink back down when temperatures cool. This expansion also causes the tower to lean slightly away from the sun as the metal on the sunny side heats up and expands more than the shaded side.
facts.verification_note: The Eiffel Tower's iron structure does expand up to 15 cm (about 6 inches) in hot weather due to thermal expansion, and differential heating does cause it to lean slightly away from the sun, with both effects reversing as temperatures cool.
facts.image_description: A split-panel scientific illustration showing the Eiffel Tower in two contrasting states: the left panel depicts a cool winter morning with the tower in crisp blue-gray tones, standing perfectly vertical with measurement markers showing its baseline height; the right panel shows a blazing summer afternoon with the sun positioned prominently in a golden-orange sky, the tower rendered in warm amber and bronze hues, visibly leaning away from the sun's position with exaggerated measurement lines indicating the 6+ inch height increase. The iron lattice structure should be detailed enough to show individual beams, with subtle visual distortion waves on the sun-facing side to suggest heat and expansion, while dramatic shadows cast across the Champ de Mars emphasize the directional lighting. Small technical annotations with arrows and dimensional callouts should frame both versions, giving it the aesthetic of an engineering diagram merged with artistic architectural rendering.
facts.image_svg:
<svg width="800" height="600" viewBox="0 0 800 600" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <!-- Background gradient split -->
  <defs>
    <!-- Winter gradient -->
    <linearGradient id="winterSky" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="0%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#a8c5dd;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#d4e4f0;stop-opacity:1" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <!-- Summer gradient -->
    <linearGradient id="summerSky" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="0%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#ff9a3c;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#ffc04d;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#ffe8a8;stop-opacity:1" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <!-- Heat wave pattern -->
    <pattern id="heatWaves" x="0" y="0" width="20" height="20" patternUnits="userSpaceOnUse">
      <path d="M0,10 Q5,5 10,10 T20,10" stroke="#ff6600" stroke-width="0.5" fill="none" opacity="0.3"/>
      <path d="M0,15 Q5,10 10,15 T20,15" stroke="#ff8800" stroke-width="0.5" fill="none" opacity="0.3"/>
    </pattern>
    
    <!-- Sun glow -->
    <radialGradient id="sunGlow">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#fff9e6;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="30%" style="stop-color:#ffcc00;stop-opacity:0.8" />
      <stop offset="70%" style="stop-color:#ff8800;stop-opacity:0.4" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#ff6600;stop-opacity:0" />
    </radialGradient>
    
    <!-- Tower structure pattern -->
    <pattern id="lattice" x="0" y="0" width="15" height="15" patternUnits="userSpaceOnUse">
      <line x1="0" y1="0" x2="15" y2="15" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="0.5" opacity="0.6"/>
      <line x1="15" y1="0" x2="0" y2="15" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="0.5" opacity="0.6"/>
    </pattern>
  </defs>
  
  <!-- Split background -->
  <rect x="0" y="0" width="400" height="600" fill="url(#winterSky)"/>
  <rect x="400" y="0" width="400" height="600" fill="url(#summerSky)"/>
  
  <!-- Divider line -->
  <line x1="400" y1="0" x2="400" y2="600" stroke="#666" stroke-width="2" stroke-dasharray="10,5"/>
  
  <!-- Winter ground -->
  <rect x="0" y="520" width="400" height="80" fill="#b8c9d9"/>
  <ellipse cx="200" cy="520" rx="180" ry="15" fill="#a0b5c8" opacity="0.5"/>
  
  <!-- Summer ground -->
  <rect x="400" y="520" width="400" height="80" fill="#d4a76a"/>
  <ellipse cx="600" cy="520" rx="180" ry="15" fill="#b88f5a" opacity="0.5"/>
  
  <!-- Sun in summer panel -->
  <circle cx="650" cy="100" r="60" fill="url(#sunGlow)"/>
  <circle cx="650" cy="100" r="35" fill="#ffdd00"/>
  <g stroke="#ffdd00" stroke-width="3" opacity="0.7">
    <line x1="650" y1="30" x2="650" y2="50"/>
    <line x1="650" y1="150" x2="650" y2="170"/>
    <line x1="580" y1="100" x2="600" y2="100"/>
    <line x1="700" y1="100" x2="720" y2="100"/>
    <line x1="595" y1="55" x2="610" y2="70"/>
    <line x1="690" y1="130" x2="705" y2="145"/>
    <line x1="595" y1="145" x2="610" y2="130"/>
    <line x1="690" y1="70" x2="705" y2="55"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Heat waves on summer side -->
  <rect x="500" y="150" width="100" height="300" fill="url(#heatWaves)"/>
  
  <!-- WINTER TOWER (LEFT) - Vertical -->
  <g id="winterTower">
    <!-- Base -->
    <polygon points="140,520 260,520 240,480 160,480" fill="#6b8ba3" stroke="#4a6b7d" stroke-width="2"/>
    <rect x="145" y="480" width="110" height="5" fill="url(#lattice)" style="color:#4a6b7d"/>
    
    <!-- Lower section -->
    <polygon points="160,480 240,480 220,380 180,380" fill="#7a9bb5" stroke="#5a7b8d" stroke-width="1.5"/>
    <rect x="165" y="380" width="70" height="100" fill="url(#lattice)" style="color:#5a7b8d" opacity="0.3"/>
    
    <!-- Middle section -->
    <polygon points="180,380 220,380 210,260 190,260" fill="#8aacc6" stroke="#6a8c9d" stroke-width="1.5"/>
    <rect x="185" y="260" width="40" height="120" fill="url(#lattice)" style="color:#6a8c9d" opacity="0.3"/>
    
    <!-- Upper section -->
    <polygon points="190,260 210,260 205,150 195,150" fill="#9abdd7" stroke="#7a9dae" stroke-width="1.5"/>
    <rect x="192" y="150" width="16" height="110" fill="url(#lattice)" style="color:#7a9dae" opacity="0.3"/>
    
    <!-- Top spire -->
    <polygon points="195,150 205,150 200,80" fill="#aacde7" stroke="#8aadbf" stroke-width="1.5"/>
    <line x1="200" y1="80" x2="200" y2="60" stroke="#8aadbf" stroke-width="2"/>
    <circle cx="200" cy="60" r="3" fill="#8aadbf"/>
    
    <!-- Measurement lines -->
    <line x1="280" y1="520" x2="280" y2="60" stroke="#2c4a5e" stroke-width="1.5" stroke-dasharray="5,3"/>
    <line x1="275" y1="520" x2="285" y2="520" stroke="#2c4a5e" stroke-width="2"/>
    <line x1="275" y1="60" x2="285" y2="60" stroke="#2c4a5e" stroke-width="2"/>
    
    <!-- Annotation arrows -->
    <path d="M290,290 L320,250" stroke="#2c4a5e" stroke-width="1.5" fill="none" marker-end="url(#arrowWinter)"/>
    <circle cx="320" cy="250" r="15" fill="#4a6b7d" opacity="0.3"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Arrow marker for winter -->

    <marker id="arrowSummer" markerWidth="10" markerHeight="10" refX="5" refY="3" orient="auto" markerUnits="strokeWidth">
      <path d="M0,0 L0,6 L9,3 z" fill="#8b4513"/>
    </marker>
  </defs>
  
  <!-- SUMMER TOWER (RIGHT) - Leaning away from sun -->
  <g id="summerTower" transform="translate(400,0)">

    <polygon points="140,520 260,520 250,480 170,480" fill="#b8894a" stroke="#8b6532" stroke-width="2"/>

    <!-- Middle section - more lean -->

    <rect x="200" y="260" width="45" height="120" fill="url(#lattice)" style="color:#a57f4a" opacity="0.3"/>
    
    <!-- Upper section - pronounced lean -->
    <polygon points="210,260 235,260 235,150 220,150" fill="#deb068" stroke="#b08952" stroke-width="1.5"/>
    <rect x="215" y="150" width="20" height="110" fill="url(#lattice)" style="color:#b08952" opacity="0.3"/>
    
    <!-- Top spire - leaning -->

    <line x1="235" y1="80" x2="240" y2="45" stroke="#ba935a" stroke-width="2"/>
    <circle cx="240" cy="45" r="3" fill="#ba935a"/>
    
    <!-- Extended measurement lines showing growth -->

    <line x1="275" y1="520" x2="285" y2="520" stroke="#8b4513" stroke-width="2"/>
    <line x1="275" y1="45" x2="285" y2="45" stroke="#8b4513" stroke-width="2"/>

    <line x1="285" y1="45" x2="300" y2="45" stroke="#8b4513" stroke-width="2"/>

facts.text: When you get a sunburn, the damaged cells in your skin commit suicide through a process called apoptosis, and the peeling you see days later is actually your body shedding these self-destructed cells. The characteristic redness occurs because dying cells release chemicals that trigger inflammation and increase blood flow to help clear away the cellular corpses.
facts.verification_note: UV radiation does cause DNA damage that triggers apoptosis in skin cells, and the subsequent peeling is indeed the shedding of these dead cells, while redness results from inflammatory mediators released during this process that cause vasodilation.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a cross-section of human skin in a semi-transparent, scientific cutaway style, showing three distinct layers with the epidermis prominently featured. Damaged skin cells in the upper layer should be rendered in warm oranges and reds, fragmenting apart in a controlled, almost choreographed manner, with glowing chemical signals (depicted as luminescent particles or waves in yellows and ambers) radiating outward from the dying cells. Below, dilated blood vessels should appear as vivid crimson rivers carrying away cellular debris, while intact healthy cells in cooler blues and purples contrast sharply with the inflamed area. The lighting should have a dramatic backlit quality, making the inflammatory chemicals appear to shimmer and pulse, with peeling dead cells at the surface curling away like delicate, translucent paper in pale whites and grays, creating a striking before-and-after narrative within a single frame.

facts.text: When you get a kidney transplant, doctors usually leave your original kidneys inside your body and place the new kidney in your lower abdomen near your groin, meaning most kidney transplant recipients end up with three kidneys. The original kidneys are only removed if they're causing infections or other serious problems.
facts.verification_note: In standard kidney transplant procedures, the native kidneys are typically left in place and the donor kidney is surgically placed in the lower abdomen (iliac fossa), resulting in three total kidneys, with native kidney removal (nephrectomy) only performed when complications like infection, uncontrolled hypertension, or polycystic kidney disease are present.
facts.image_description: A cutaway medical illustration showing a translucent human torso in soft peach and blue tones, with the spine and ribcage faintly visible in pale gray. Two original kidneys in deep burgundy red are positioned high in the back near the ribcage, while a third, slightly pinker transplanted kidney sits lower in the front pelvic region, connected to the bladder with clearly visible arterial tubes in bright red and venous connections in blue. The style should be clean and educational like a modern anatomy textbook, with a subtle glow highlighting each kidney against the semi-transparent body, and thin white labels with arrows pointing to "Original Kidneys" and "Transplanted Kidney" to emphasize the surprising three-kidney configuration.

    <!-- Arrow to right original kidney -->
    <path d="M 540 200 L 515 210" marker-end="url(#arrowhead1)"/>
    <!-- Arrow to transplanted kidney -->

  </g>

  <circle cx="480" cy="220" r="65" fill="none" stroke="#ffccaa" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.3"/>

facts.text: When a glass shatters, the cracks propagate through it at speeds up to 3,000 miles per hour—faster than a speeding bullet—but high-speed cameras reveal the fractures branch and split in patterns that perfectly mirror the structure of lightning bolts, following the same mathematical rules that govern how rivers form and how your lungs branch.
facts.verification_note: Crack propagation in glass does reach speeds around 3,000 mph (roughly half the speed of sound in glass), and fracture patterns, lightning, river networks, and lung branching all follow similar fractal branching patterns governed by principles of energy minimization and diffusion-limited aggregation.
facts.image_description: The illustration shows a wine glass frozen mid-shatter in dramatic slow-motion, with luminous white and electric-blue fracture lines radiating through the transparent glass like captured lightning. The cracks branch and split in intricate, tree-like patterns that mirror three ghosted overlays in the background: a pale blue lightning bolt, translucent pink lung bronchioles, and silvery river tributaries, all sharing identical branching angles and mathematical proportions. The style blends photorealistic glass physics with scientific diagram aesthetics, using a dark gradient background that transitions from deep navy to black, while speed-blur trails behind the fastest-moving crack tips glow with orange-red heat to visualize their bullet-like 3,000 mph velocity. Subtle numerical annotations and trajectory lines arc around the glass like a technical schematic, with one crack tip measurement reading "3,000 mph" in crisp white text, while the fractal dimension formula "D≈1.7" appears faintly in the corner, connecting all four branching patterns.

facts.text: The mantis shrimp can throw punches so fast that they create cavitation bubbles in the water, which collapse with a flash of light and temperatures reaching nearly 8,000°F—almost as hot as the surface of the sun—capable of killing prey even if the punch itself misses.
facts.verification_note: Mantis shrimp strikes do create cavitation bubbles that collapse producing sonoluminescence (light flashes) and temperatures around 4,700-8,000°F, comparable to the sun's surface (~10,000°F), with the secondary shockwave capable of stunning or killing prey.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a vibrant peacock mantis shrimp in mid-strike, its club-like appendage extended in a blur of motion, rendered in photorealistic detail with iridescent greens, blues, and oranges against a deep turquoise ocean background. At the point of impact, translucent spherical cavitation bubbles should be forming and collapsing in sequence, with the collapsing bubbles emitting brilliant white-yellow flashes of light that create dramatic lens flares and illuminate the surrounding water particles. Small temperature indicators or heat-map overlays in red and orange could subtly frame the impact zone, while a small stunned fish floats nearby, showing the deadly effectiveness of the strike. The composition should use motion blur on the striking appendage and sharp focus on the bubbles' luminescence, creating a dynamic sense of explosive power frozen in a split-second moment, with scientific accuracy balanced by dramatic, almost supernatural lighting that emphasizes the extreme temperatures involved.

  <g opacity="0.7">
    <line x1="485" y1="270" x2="505" y2="290" stroke="#ffffff" stroke-width="2.5" opacity="0.5" filter="url(#glow)"/>
    <line x1="485" y1="270" x2="515" y2="285" stroke="#ffff88" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.6" filter="url(#glow)"/>
    <circle cx="505" cy="290" r="3" fill="#ffffff" opacity="0.7"/>
    <circle cx="515" cy="285" r="2.5" fill="#ffffbb" opacity="0.6"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- More forming bubbles -->

  <circle cx="478" cy="258" r="9" fill="url(#bubble1)" opacity="0.55" filter="url(#glow)"/>
  <circle cx="492" cy="280" r="13" fill="url(#bubble1)" opacity="0.7" filter="url(#glow)"/>

  <circle cx="505" cy="285" r="2.5" fill="#ffee88" opacity="0.75" filter="url(#glow)"/>
