facts.text: When a dying star goes supernova, the explosion produces so much energy that for a brief moment, it can outshine an entire galaxy of 100 billion stars. The iron in your blood was forged in such an explosion billions of years ago, making you literally made of stardust from a stellar corpse.
facts.verification_note: Supernovae can indeed briefly outshine their host galaxies with absolute magnitudes around -19 to -20, and iron is produced through nucleosynthesis in massive stars and dispersed during supernova explosions, making the claim scientifically accurate.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a massive supernova explosion dominating the center of the frame, rendered in photorealistic style with a brilliant white-gold core surrounded by concentric shockwaves of crimson, orange, and electric blue plasma expanding outward. In the background, a spiral galaxy filled with billions of dimmer stars appears washed out and pale in comparison to the supernova's overwhelming luminosity. In the foreground, ghostly transparent human silhouettes or anatomical overlays should show glowing iron atoms (represented as small red-orange points of light) flowing through blood vessels and collecting in a beating heart, with delicate golden threads connecting these iron atoms back to the supernova, creating a visual bridge between the cosmic explosion and human biology. The color palette should emphasize the contrast between the supernova's intense warm yellows and oranges against the cool deep blues and purples of space, with the iron particles glowing like embers to reinforce their stellar origin.

facts.text: Neutron stars are so dense that a teaspoon of their material would weigh about 6 billion tons on Earth—roughly the same as if Mount Everest were compressed into something you could hold in your hand. The gravity is so intense that if you dropped an object from just one meter above the surface, it would hit the ground at around 7 million kilometers per hour.
facts.verification_note: The density claim is accurate (neutron star material is approximately 4-6 × 10^14 g/cm³, making a teaspoon weigh billions of tons), and the calculated impact velocity from 1 meter drop on a neutron star surface with typical gravity of ~10^12 m/s² yields approximately 4-7 million km/h, matching the stated figure.
facts.image_description: The illustration shows a split composition in a dramatic photorealistic style with scientific diagram elements: on the left, a glowing teaspoon hovers above a neutron star's surface, rendered in deep purples and electric blues with magnetic field lines crackling around it, while the spoon itself appears to warp spacetime around it like a gravitational lens. On the right, for scale comparison, a ghostly translucent Mount Everest is compressed and flowing into an identical teaspoon, with its massive snow-covered peak dissolving into swirling matter. At the bottom, a small spherical object is shown in three positions descending one meter to the surface, with motion blur intensifying to a white-hot streak, accompanied by a speed indicator displaying "7,000,000 km/h" in glowing text. The neutron star's surface below features a geometric crystalline lattice structure in iridescent grays, backlit by the star's own radiation creating an otherworldly rim lighting effect.

<svg width="800" height="600" viewBox="0 0 800 600" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">

    <path d="M 550 500 L 600 480 L 650 500 L 600 520 Z" fill="none" stroke="#818cf8" stroke-width="1"/>

    <path d="M 0 -100 L -15 -70 L 15 -70 Z" fill="#ffffff" opacity="0.6"/>
    
    <!-- Matter flow/compression effect -->
    <path d="M -20 10 Q -15 20 -10 30 Q -5 35 0 38" fill="none" stroke="#7dd3fc" stroke-width="3" opacity="0.5"/>
    <path d="M 20 10 Q 15 20 10 30 Q 5 35 0 38" fill="none" stroke="#7dd3fc" stroke-width="3" opacity="0.5"/>
    <path d="M -10 15 Q -5 25 0 38" fill="none" stroke="#bae6fd" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.4"/>
    <path d="M 10 15 Q 5 25 0 38" fill="none" stroke="#bae6fd" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.4"/>
    
    <!-- Swirling particles -->
    <circle cx="-15" cy="20" r="2" fill="#93c5fd" opacity="0.6"/>
    <circle cx="15" cy="25" r="2" fill="#93c5fd" opacity="0.6"/>
    <circle cx="-8" cy="30" r="1.5" fill="#bae6fd" opacity="0.7"/>
    <circle cx="8" cy="32" r="1.5" fill="#bae6fd" opacity="0.7"/>
    
    <!-- Teaspoon (receiving) -->
    <ellipse cx="0" cy="45" rx="22" ry="16" fill="#a1a1aa" opacity="0.7"/>
    <rect x="-3.5" y="61" width="7" height="30" rx="2" fill="#b4b4b8" opacity="0.7"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- BOTTOM: Falling object demonstration -->
  <g transform="translate(400, 380)">
    <!-- Position 1: Starting point -->
    <circle cx="-100" cy="0" r="8" fill="#fbbf24" opacity="0.4"/>
    <circle cx="-100" cy="0" r="5" fill="#f59e0b" opacity="0.6"/>
    
    <!-- Position 2: Mid-fall -->
    <ellipse cx="-50" cy="30" rx="10" ry="7" fill="#fbbf24" opacity="0.5"/>
    <circle cx="-50" cy="30" r="6" fill="#f59e0b" opacity="0.7"/>
    
    <!-- Position 3: Impact with motion blur -->
    <ellipse cx="0" cy="70" rx="25" ry="8" fill="url(#speedGlow)" filter="url(#strongGlow)"/>
    <ellipse cx="10" cy="70" rx="30" ry="6" fill="#fef3c7" opacity="0.6"/>
    <ellipse cx="20" cy="70" rx="35" ry="4" fill="#fde68a" opacity="0.4"/>
    <circle cx="0" cy="70" r="7" fill="#ffffff" filter="url(#strongGlow)"/>
    
    <!-- Motion trail -->
    <path d="M -100 0 Q -75 15 -50 30 Q -25 50 0 70" fill="none" stroke="#fbbf24" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.3" stroke-dasharray="5,5"/>
    
    <!-- Speed indicator display -->
    <g transform="translate(60, 60)">
      <rect x="0" y="0" width="140" height="35" rx="5" fill="#1f2937" opacity="0.9" stroke="#fbbf24" stroke-width="2"/>
      <text x="70" y="14" font-family="Arial, sans-serif" font-size="12" fill="#fbbf24" text-anchor="middle" font-weight="bold">7,000,000</text>
      <text x="70" y="28" font-family="Arial, sans-serif" font-size="10" fill="#f59e0b" text-anchor="middle">km/h</text>
    </g>
    
    <!-- Impact shockwave -->
    <ellipse cx="0" cy="70" rx="40" ry="10" fill="none" stroke="#fbbf24" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.3"/>
    <ellipse cx="0" cy="70" rx="55" ry="15" fill="none" stroke="#f59e0b" stroke-width="1" opacity="0.2"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Spacetime distortion grid on left -->
  <g opacity="0.2">
    <path d="M 50 200 Q 200 220 350 200" fill="none" stroke="#8b5cf6" stroke-width="1"/>
    <path d="M 50 230 Q 200 255 350 230" fill="none" stroke="#8b5cf6" stroke-width="1"/>
    <path d="M 50 260 Q 200 290 350 260" fill="none" stroke="#8b5cf6" stroke-width="1"/>
    <path d="M 50 290 Q 200 325 350 290" fill="none" stroke="#8b5cf6" stroke-width="1"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Additional atmospheric glow -->
  <ellipse cx="200" cy="250" rx="150" ry="120" fill="url(#neutronStarGlow)" opacity="0.3"/>
  
  <!-- Dividing line (subtle) -->
  <line x1="400" y1="100" x2="400" y2="400" stroke="#6366f1" stroke-width="1" opacity="0.2" stroke-dasharray="10,10"/>
</svg>

facts.text: Wombats are the only animals that produce cube-shaped feces, which they stack to mark territory. Their intestines have varying elasticity in different sections, combined with long digestion times, which literally molds their waste into cubes that won't roll away on slopes.
facts.verification_note: Scientific research has confirmed that wombats produce cube-shaped feces due to differential elasticity in their intestinal walls combined with extended digestion times, and they do use these non-rolling cubes to mark territory on rocks and logs.
facts.image_description: The illustration should show a cross-sectional view split into two halves: the left side displaying a photorealistic wombat in its natural Australian bush habitat at golden hour, with visible cube-shaped droppings stacked deliberately on a sloped rock surface, while the right side reveals a detailed anatomical cutaway of the wombat's digestive system in scientific illustration style, with the intestines color-coded in gradients from pink to deep purple to show varying elasticity zones. The intestinal walls should have visible texture differences—some sections appearing stretchy and flexible, others rigid—with small cube-shaped forms gradually taking shape along the digestive tract, highlighted with subtle directional arrows and measurement indicators. The background should feature soft-focus eucalyptus trees and native grasses, with warm amber and green tones contrasting against the clinical precision of the anatomical detail, while a few finished cubes in the foreground catch dappled sunlight, emphasizing their remarkably geometric edges and faces.

facts.text: The Hawaiian island of Maui is home to a species of carnivorous caterpillar that hunts by lying motionless like a twig, then striking with lightning speed to grab passing insects with its clawed legs. This is the only known case of caterpillars evolving to become active predators rather than plant-eaters.
facts.verification_note: Eupithecia caterpillars in Hawaii are indeed documented ambush predators that use modified legs to capture prey, representing a unique evolutionary adaptation from herbivory to carnivory among Lepidoptera larvae.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a photorealistic close-up of a twig-like caterpillar in mid-strike on a dark volcanic rock surface dappled with golden Hawaiian sunlight filtering through native ferns. The caterpillar's body should be rendered in mottled browns and greens with bark-like texture, perfectly camouflaged until the moment of action—its front segments reared up dramatically with specialized clawed legs extended toward an unsuspecting small fly, frozen in the decisive moment of contact. The background should be softly blurred to emphasize the drama, showing hints of Maui's misty rainforest environment, while the foreground maintains razor-sharp detail on the caterpillar's surprising predatory features: the hooked legs, segmented body tension, and the contrast between its plant-like disguise and violent hunting behavior. A subtle motion blur on the striking legs would convey the "lightning speed" while maintaining scientific accuracy in a style reminiscent of National Geographic wildlife photography.

facts.text: When you get a brain freeze from eating ice cream too quickly, the pain you feel is actually referred to from the roof of your mouth—your brain itself has no pain receptors and cannot feel pain. The cold causes blood vessels in the palate to rapidly constrict and then dilate, triggering pain signals that your brain interprets as coming from your forehead due to overlapping nerve pathways.
facts.verification_note: The claim accurately describes the mechanism of ice cream headache (sphenopalatine ganglioneuralgia), including the correct facts that the brain lacks pain receptors, the pain originates from rapid vascular changes in the palate, and referred pain occurs due to convergence of trigeminal nerve pathways.
facts.image_description: A split-panel scientific illustration showing a translucent side-view of a human head in cool blues and purples, with one half depicting the moment of ice cream contact. The roof of the mouth glows in intense red-orange where the cold ice cream touches, with animated blood vessels visibly constricting (shown as thin lines) then dilating (thickening dramatically). Bright yellow-white neural pathways arc upward from the palate through the facial region, branching and converging toward the forehead area where they burst into radiating red pain signals, like electrical sparks. The brain itself remains in calm, muted gray-blue tones with a subtle transparent quality, emphasizing its inability to feel pain, while a small ice cream cone in the foreground provides scale and context with its creamy white and pastel colors contrasting against the medical diagram aesthetic.

facts.text: Tardigrades, microscopic animals also known as water bears, can survive being frozen at -272°C (just one degree above absolute zero), boiled at 150°C, exposed to the vacuum of space, and blasted with radiation 1,000 times stronger than what would kill a human. When conditions become unbearable, they expel nearly all water from their bodies and enter a death-like state called cryptobiosis, where they can remain for decades before springing back to life when rehydrated.
facts.verification_note: All claims are scientifically documented, including tardigrades' survival at extreme temperatures (-272°C and 150°C), vacuum and radiation exposure in space experiments, cryptobiotic desiccation processes, and revival after decades of dormancy.
facts.image_description: The illustration should depict a magnified tardigrade as the central figure, rendered in a semi-translucent, crystalline style that shows its iconic eight-legged, bear-like form with intricate segmentation and clawed feet. The composition should split into four quadrants surrounding the tardigrade, each showing extreme conditions: deep space's star-studded void with cosmic radiation (purple and blue auroras), crackling ice crystals in ultra-frozen darkness (pale blues and whites), bubbling intense heat with orange-red gradients, and a dehydrated, shriveled tun state glowing amber against a dark background. The lighting should create a dramatic contrast between the pearlescent, almost ghostly tardigrade body and the harsh environments, using bioluminescent blues and teals for the creature itself, while maintaining scientific accuracy in its anatomical details like the tube-like mouth and stubby legs. The overall style should blend photorealistic microscopy with ethereal, almost supernatural lighting to emphasize both the creature's alien beauty and its remarkable resilience, with fine details showing individual body segments and the texture of its cuticle.

    <!-- Right legs -->

facts.text: When a caterpillar transforms into a butterfly inside its chrysalis, it doesn't just grow wings—it first digests itself into a protein-rich soup using enzymes, dissolving most of its body into cellular goo. Only a few specialized cell clusters called "imaginal discs" survive this process to rebuild the creature entirely from scratch into its adult form.
facts.verification_note: During metamorphosis, caterpillars do release enzymes that break down most tissues into a nutrient-rich fluid while imaginal discs, which were present since the larval stage, use this material to construct the adult butterfly body.
facts.image_description: A cross-sectioned chrysalis rendered in luminous, translucent jade-green reveals the metamorphosis within, split vertically to show three distinct stages from left to right: a dissolving caterpillar body melting into an ethereal, amber-gold liquid soup with visible enzyme particles like glowing microscopic stars, then the soup itself with small, jewel-like imaginal discs floating as brilliant purple and blue cellular clusters, and finally these discs actively constructing the emerging butterfly form with gossamer wings unfurling in iridescent oranges and blacks. The illustration should blend scientific accuracy with dreamlike beauty—part medical textbook precision, part surrealist art—with dramatic backlighting that makes the chrysalis glow like stained glass and causes the protein soup to shimmer with an otherworldly bioluminescence. Delicate labels and arrows in elegant script identify the imaginal discs, dissolved tissue, and enzyme activity, while the background fades to deep twilight purple to emphasize the miraculous transformation occurring within this translucent chamber.

facts.text: When you get a sunburn, the damaged skin cells commit suicide by self-destructing their own DNA to prevent becoming cancerous—and it's actually this mass cellular suicide over the following days that causes your skin to peel, not the initial UV damage itself.
facts.verification_note: UV-damaged keratinocytes undergo programmed cell death (apoptosis) to prevent mutations from becoming cancerous, and this delayed apoptotic process, peaking 24-72 hours post-exposure, causes the characteristic skin peeling days after sunburn rather than the immediate UV damage.
facts.image_description: A split-panel scientific illustration showing a cross-section of skin in warm, glowing tones: the left side depicts healthy pink skin cells with intact nuclei in soft peachy hues, while the right side shows the dramatic transformation after sun exposure—damaged cells with fragmenting DNA strands (visualized as breaking blue double helices) triggering apoptosis, rendered in deeper reds and oranges with some cells already detaching. The cellular level should be magnified and semi-transparent, revealing the choreographed self-destruction process with glowing golden UV rays penetrating from above, while dying cells lift away like autumn leaves in pale, translucent layers. The style should blend medical textbook precision with ethereal beauty, using a backlit quality that makes the DNA fragments sparkle like shattered crystals, and subtle arrows or dotted lines showing the progression from UV exposure to cellular suicide to the final peeling effect, all set against a gradient background transitioning from sunny yellow to healing pink.
facts.image_svg:
<svg width="800" height="600" viewBox="0 0 800 600" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <defs>
    <linearGradient id="bgGradient" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="0%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#FFD700;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="50%" style="stop-color:#FFA07A;stop-opacity:1" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#FFB6C1;stop-opacity:1" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <linearGradient id="healthyCell" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#FFB6C1;stop-opacity:0.8" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#FFC0CB;stop-opacity:0.9" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <linearGradient id="damagedCell" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="100%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#FF6347;stop-opacity:0.9" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#FF4500;stop-opacity:0.8" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <radialGradient id="nucleus" cx="50%" cy="50%" r="50%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#FF69B4;stop-opacity:0.9" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#FF1493;stop-opacity:0.7" />
    </radialGradient>
    
    <radialGradient id="damagedNucleus" cx="50%" cy="50%" r="50%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#8B0000;stop-opacity:0.8" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#DC143C;stop-opacity:0.6" />
    </radialGradient>
    
    <linearGradient id="uvRay" x1="0%" y1="0%" x2="0%" y2="100%">
      <stop offset="0%" style="stop-color:#FFD700;stop-opacity:0.9" />
      <stop offset="100%" style="stop-color:#FFA500;stop-opacity:0.3" />
    </linearGradient>
    
    <filter id="glow">
      <feGaussianBlur stdDeviation="3" result="coloredBlur"/>
      <feMerge>
        <feMergeNode in="coloredBlur"/>
        <feMergeNode in="SourceGraphic"/>
      </feMerge>
    </filter>
    
    <filter id="sparkle">
      <feGaussianBlur stdDeviation="2" result="coloredBlur"/>
      <feMerge>
        <feMergeNode in="coloredBlur"/>
        <feMergeNode in="SourceGraphic"/>
      </feMerge>
    </filter>
  </defs>
  
  <rect width="800" height="600" fill="url(#bgGradient)"/>
  
  <!-- UV Rays from top -->
  <g opacity="0.7">
    <path d="M 100 0 L 110 200 L 90 200 Z" fill="url(#uvRay)" filter="url(#glow)"/>
    <path d="M 200 0 L 210 220 L 190 220 Z" fill="url(#uvRay)" filter="url(#glow)"/>
    <path d="M 300 0 L 310 200 L 290 200 Z" fill="url(#uvRay)" filter="url(#glow)"/>
    <path d="M 500 0 L 510 230 L 490 230 Z" fill="url(#uvRay)" filter="url(#glow)"/>
    <path d="M 600 0 L 610 210 L 590 210 Z" fill="url(#uvRay)" filter="url(#glow)"/>
    <path d="M 700 0 L 710 200 L 690 200 Z" fill="url(#uvRay)" filter="url(#glow)"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Left side: Healthy skin cells -->
  <g opacity="0.85">
    <!-- Cell 1 -->
    <ellipse cx="150" cy="250" rx="45" ry="40" fill="url(#healthyCell)" stroke="#FFB6C1" stroke-width="2"/>
    <circle cx="150" cy="250" r="15" fill="url(#nucleus)"/>
    <path d="M 145 245 Q 150 240 155 245 Q 150 250 145 245" fill="none" stroke="#4169E1" stroke-width="1.5" opacity="0.8"/>
    
    <!-- Cell 2 -->
    <ellipse cx="120" cy="330" rx="40" ry="38" fill="url(#healthyCell)" stroke="#FFB6C1" stroke-width="2"/>
    <circle cx="120" cy="330" r="14" fill="url(#nucleus)"/>
    <path d="M 115 325 Q 120 320 125 325 Q 120 330 115 325" fill="none" stroke="#4169E1" stroke-width="1.5" opacity="0.8"/>
    
    <!-- Cell 3 -->
    <ellipse cx="180" cy="340" rx="42" ry="39" fill="url(#healthyCell)" stroke="#FFB6C1" stroke-width="2"/>
    <circle cx="180" cy="340" r="13" fill="url(#nucleus)"/>
    <path d="M 175 335 Q 180 330 185 335 Q 180 340 175 335" fill="none" stroke="#4169E1" stroke-width="1.5" opacity="0.8"/>
    
    <!-- Cell 4 -->
    <ellipse cx="150" cy="410" rx="44" ry="40" fill="url(#healthyCell)" stroke="#FFB6C1" stroke-width="2"/>
    <circle cx="150" cy="410" r="14" fill="url(#nucleus)"/>
    <path d="M 145 405 Q 150 400 155 405 Q 150 410 145 405" fill="none" stroke="#4169E1" stroke-width="1.5" opacity="0.8"/>
    
    <!-- Cell 5 -->
    <ellipse cx="210" cy="270" rx="40" ry="37" fill="url(#healthyCell)" stroke="#FFB6C1" stroke-width="2"/>
    <circle cx="210" cy="270" r="13" fill="url(#nucleus)"/>
    <path d="M 205 265 Q 210 260 215 265 Q 210 270 205 265" fill="none" stroke="#4169E1" stroke-width="1.5" opacity="0.8"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Dividing line -->
  <line x1="400" y1="150" x2="400" y2="600" stroke="#FFD700" stroke-width="3" stroke-dasharray="10,5" opacity="0.6"/>
  
  <!-- Right side: Damaged cells with apoptosis -->
  <g>
    <!-- Damaged Cell 1 - fragmenting -->
    <ellipse cx="550" cy="260" rx="45" ry="40" fill="url(#damagedCell)" stroke="#FF4500" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.8"/>
    <circle cx="550" cy="260" r="15" fill="url(#damagedNucleus)"/>
    <!-- Broken DNA strands -->
    <path d="M 545 255 L 540 250" stroke="#4169E1" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.9" filter="url(#sparkle)"/>
    <path d="M 555 255 L 560 250" stroke="#4169E1" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.9" filter="url(#sparkle)"/>
    <path d="M 545 265 L 540 270" stroke="#4169E1" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.9" filter="url(#sparkle)"/>
    <circle cx="540" cy="250" r="2" fill="#87CEEB" filter="url(#sparkle)"/>
    <circle cx="560" cy="250" r="2" fill="#87CEEB" filter="url(#sparkle)"/>
    <circle cx="540" cy="270" r="2" fill="#87CEEB" filter="url(#sparkle)"/>
    
    <!-- Damaged Cell 2 - severe fragmentation -->
    <ellipse cx="520" cy="340" rx="42" ry="38" fill="url(#damagedCell)" stroke="#FF4500" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.7"/>
    <ellipse cx="520" cy="340" r="14" fill="url(#damagedNucleus)" opacity="0.6"/>
    <path d="M 515 335 L 505 325" stroke="#4169E1" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.9" filter="url(#sparkle)"/>
    <path d="M 525 335 L 535 325" stroke="#4169E1" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.9" filter="url(#sparkle)"/>
    <path d="M 515 345 L 505 355" stroke="#4169E1" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.9" filter="url(#sparkle)"/>
    <path d="M 525 345 L 535 355" stroke="#4169E1" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.9" filter="url(#sparkle)"/>
    <circle cx="505" cy="325" r="2.5" fill="#87CEEB" filter="url(#sparkle)"/>
    <circle cx="535" cy="325" r="2.5" fill="#87CEEB" filter="url(#sparkle)"/>
    <circle cx="505" cy="355" r="2.5" fill="#87CEEB" filter="url(#sparkle)"/>
    <circle cx="535" cy="355" r="2.5" fill="#87CEEB" filter="url(#sparkle)"/>
    
    <!-- Damaged Cell 3 -->
    <ellipse cx="590" cy="350" rx="40" ry="37" fill="url(#damagedCell)" stroke="#FF4500" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.75"/>
    <circle cx="590" cy="350" r="13" fill="url(#damagedNucleus)" opacity="0.7"/>
    <path d="M 585 345 L 575 335" stroke="#4169E1" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.9" filter="url(#sparkle)"/>
    <path d="M 595 345 L 605 335" stroke="#4169E1" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.9" filter="url(#sparkle)"/>
    <circle cx="575" cy="335" r="2" fill="#87CEEB" filter="url(#sparkle)"/>
    <circle cx="605" cy="335" r="2" fill="#87CEEB" filter="url(#sparkle)"/>
    
    <!-- Damaged Cell 4 - deep layer -->
    <ellipse cx="560" cy="420" rx="43" ry="39" fill="url(#damagedCell)" stroke="#FF4500" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.8"/>
    <circle cx="560" cy="420" r="14" fill="url(#damagedNucleus)"/>
    <path d="M 555 415 L 550 410" stroke="#4169E1" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.9" filter="url(#sparkle)"/>
    <path d="M 565 415 L 570 410" stroke="#4169E1" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.9" filter="url(#sparkle)"/>
    <circle cx="550" cy="410" r="2" fill="#87CEEB" filter="url(#sparkle)"/>
    <circle cx="570" cy="410" r="2" fill="#87CEEB" filter="url(#sparkle)"/>
    
    <!-- Damaged Cell 5 -->
    <ellipse cx="620" cy="280" rx="41" ry="38" fill="url(#damagedCell)" stroke="#FF4500" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.8"/>
    <circle cx="620" cy="280" r="13" fill="url(#damagedNucleus)"/>
    <path d="M 615 275 L 610 270" stroke="#4169E1" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.9" filter="url(#sparkle)"/>
    <path d="M 625 275 L 630 270" stroke="#4169E1" stroke-width="2" opacity="0.9" filter="url(#sparkle)"/>
    <circle cx="610" cy="270" r="2" fill="#87CEEB" filter="url(#sparkle)"/>
    <circle cx="630" cy="270" r="2" fill="#87CEEB" filter="url(#sparkle)"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Peeling cells - floating away like autumn leaves -->
  <g opacity="0.6">
    <ellipse cx="480" cy="180" rx="35" ry="30" fill="#FFB6C1" opacity="0.4" stroke="#FFA07A" stroke-width="1"/>
    <ellipse cx="520" cy="150" rx="30" ry="28" fill="#FFDAB9" opacity="0.3" stroke="#FFA07A" stroke-width="1"/>
    <ellipse cx="580" cy="160" rx="32" ry="29" fill="#FFE4E1" opacity="0.35" stroke="#FFA07A" stroke-width="1"/>
    <ellipse cx="640" cy="140" rx="28" ry="26" fill="#FFF0F5" opacity="0.3" stroke="#FFA07A" stroke-width="1"/>
    <ellipse cx="550" cy="120" rx="30" ry="27" fill="#FFDAB9" opacity="0.25" stroke="#FFA07A" stroke-width="1"/>
    <ellipse cx="610" cy="110" rx="26" ry="24" fill="#FFE4E1" opacity="0.2" stroke="#FFA07A" stroke-width="1"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Arrows showing progression -->
  <g opacity="0.7">
    <!-- Arrow from UV to damaged cells -->
    <path d="M 300 180 Q 350 200 400 220" fill="none" stroke="#FFD700" stroke-width="2" stroke-dasharray="5,3"/>
    <polygon points="400,220 395,215 395,225" fill="#FFD700"/>
    
    <!-- Arrow from damaged cells to peeling -->
    <path d="M 550 240 Q 540 200 530 170" fill="none" stroke="#FFA07A" stroke-width="2" stroke-dasharray="5,3"/>
    <polygon points="530,170 525,175 535,175" fill="#FFA07A"/>
  </g>
  
  <!-- Additional DNA fragments scattered -->
  <g filter="url(#sparkle)">
    <circle cx="490" cy="310" r="2" fill="#87CEEB" opacity="0.8"/>
    <circle cx="510" cy="295" r="2.5" fill="#87CEEB" opacity="0.9"/>
    <circle cx="570" cy="305" r="2" fill="#87CEEB" opacity="0.8"/>
    <circle cx="600" cy="320" r="2.5" fill="#87CEEB" opacity="0.9"/>
    <circle cx="540" cy="380" r="2" fill="#87CEEB" opacity="0.8"/>
    <circle cx="590" cy="390" r="2.5" fill="#87CEEB" opacity="0.9"/>
    <line x1="488" y1="310" x2="492" y2="310" stroke="#4169E1" stroke-width="1.5" opacity="0.7"/>
    <line x1="508" y1="295" x2="512" y2="295" stroke="#4169E1" stroke-width="1.5" opacity="0.7"/>
    <line x1="568" y1="305" x2="572" y2="305" stroke="#4169E1" stroke-width="1.5" opacity="0.7"/>
  </g>
</svg>
